hh: The presence and spread of the tsetse fly in various regions of Africa significantly impacted livestock and agricultural practices, influenced colonial settlement and economic strategies, and posed challenges for both local populations and colonial administrators in managing ecological and economic development.
result: The presence and spread of the tsetse fly in various regions of Africa significantly impacted livestock and agricultural practices, influenced colonial settlement and economic strategies, and posed challenges for both local populations and colonial administrators. Observations from the General History of Africa textbook highlight the British efforts to combat sleeping sickness by implementing ecological interventions, such as preventing game from using waterholes, clearing bush, and relocating populations. These actions indicate that the tsetse fly influenced colonial strategies and settlement patterns, posing challenges for local populations. However, the textbook primarily focuses on health implications and colonial responses, lacking detailed information on the fly's impact on agriculture and livestock. In contrast, The African Times news articles provide specific details about the tsetse fly's detrimental effects on cattle and other domestic animals in regions like Zululand, Rovuma, and Umswezwi, aligning with the claim of its significant impact on livestock practices. The articles also discuss the challenges the fly posed to colonial settlement and economic strategies, such as influencing the choice of locations for model farms and complicating livestock transportation. While the articles highlight the fly's association with large game and unoccupied areas, influencing land use and settlement decisions, they do not explicitly connect the tsetse fly to broader agricultural practices or economic development strategies. Together, these sources suggest that while the tsetse fly was a significant concern, its influence on broader agricultural and economic strategies may not have been as extensively documented, with each source providing complementary insights into its impact.

Some of them even went outside their own localities to establish empires. In the 1860s the Arabs managed to have Mnwa Sele deposed and replaced by Mkasiwa, and Mnwa Sele's brother Simba left Unyanyembe to set up his kingdom among the Konongo to the south-west of Tabora. Another member of the chiefly family in Unyan› yembe called Nyungu ya Ma we left his country in 1874 to establish a well-organized kingdom among the Wakimbu to the south-west of the Wanyamwezi. Besides such rulers who went away from their traditional states to subdue a number of small states to form larger ones, there were also examples of states that expanded because of the increased power of their rulers. Mirambo's state is the most striking example, but there were many others. Mtinginya of Usongo in north-eastern Unyamwezi was a hereditary ruler who took advantage of the trade route to Karagwe and Buganda to strengthen and expand his state. Even Isike, the successor of Mkasiwa in Unyanyembe, became powerful enough to offer the Arabs and later the Germans a great deal of resistance.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the social field', 'content': 'The neglect of technical and industrial education and the emphasis on liberal and clerical training and the consequent love for white-collar jobs also created among the educated folk disdain for manual labour and agricul› tural work which is still with us. Furthermore, the uneven nature of the distribution of educational facilities prevented a uniform process of modernization in each colony, which further accentuated differences and tensions between ethnic groups and regions. These have remained in many areas and underlie some of the civil wars and rivalries that have occurred in some independent African states. The neglect of higher education and technical training also compelled some Africans who could afford to do so, to send their children to the metropolitan countries as well as to the United States, and it was such people who, partly from their varying experiences of racial discrimination and, even more important still, their deeper appreciation of the evil nature of the colonial system, became on their return, as will be shown in the next volume, the most bitter critics of the system and the leaders of the anti-colonial or nationalist movements.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}]

[{'id': 103, 'article_title': 'CHRISTIANSBORG.', 'full_section_title': 'CHRISTIANSBORG.', 'last_edit_date': '01-12-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-10', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': "You ask me about _camels_. They have never been tried here, because the experiments are very expensive. We made some trial with donkeys, but did not then succeed; still I have no doubt that donkeys would do well here. The missionaries beyond the Volta have imported a few donkeys and mules, which do very well. Horses live on our part of the coast, and on the Aquapem mountains, but not on the foot of the mountains. I believe the tzetze of Dr. Livingstone is the reason, which will also damage bullocks. We intend to make a trial of rubbing them with croupee-oil, as I am told they do in Gambia. We have not such a dense bush here that the clearing would do much. The tzetze lives where large game is, and it is said they like places, too, where maize is in blossom.

I believe it is high time to commence meteorological observations in our part of Africa. We do not even know the quantity of rain falling here. I have conversed with two missionaries, who would be willing to make observations, one at Christiansborg, one at Akrogyong on the mountains. I myself shall remove to Abokobi, on the foot of the mountain, in those days, to take charge of a girl's boarding school. Thus we would have the three essential points for observation, and the necessary trustworthy persons. But now the instruments. Would not the Royal Geographical Society do something in furnishing us with the necessary instruments; say, some thermometers, a rain-gauge, a hygrometer, or a thermometer with a wet bulb, to establish the dewpoint? If a barometer could be added it would be of great service. We would pledge ourselves to make careful observations, and to send from time to time copies of our observations to the society. Should there exist a pamphlet which would give the necessary instruction how to use these instruments, with formulas of tables which should be kept, &c., we would be thankful. We have studied natural philosophy as part of our education; but I, at least, am not acquainted with all the newer improvements. In short, here are some willing hands to assist in making known our meteorological phenomena, if somebody will use our service. As it is difficult to transport barometers, or even thermometers, such instruments should be given in charge to a friendly captain of a merchant vessel, who would be able to deliver them safely to us. Many thanks for your trouble in getting a theodolote for me.—I am, my dear Sir, faithfully yours,"}, {'id': 115, 'article_title': 'NATAL.', 'full_section_title': 'NATAL.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-22', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': '"Sir,—Allow me, through your paper, to call the attention of the public to the coming crisis in the labour market! Cultivation of land is immensely increasing, and is likely to increase more, as sugar, with sufficient labour and proper management (as far as my opinion goes), is sure to do well, and doubtless many other products besides; I find that food is plentiful at the kraals, and many Kafirs are returning home. Those that are left do less work, are more insolent, and constantly demanding higher wages, and I believe we (the cultivators) will shortly have to bid against each other who will give the highest wages, in order to weed and reap our crops. As the working Kafirs have already more money than they well know what to do with, they are sure to become worse and worse as they get higher and higher wages, and no enterprise dependent on them can ultimately pay; look forward, and a terrible result can easily be seen—ignorance, independence, and bloodshed! Before too late, let me advise all to procure sufficient coolies to reap and bring their produce to market. Employ Kafirs as many as you like, to do extra work and take in fresh land, but have coolies enough to do without Kafirs, if necessary. I cannot understand a man risking his money, or a merchant rendering assistance to a planter who relies on such uncertain labour as Natal Kafirs. In proof of the sincerity of my opinion, I may add that I employ fifty-seven coolie men, and I have written an application for fifty more!—Yours, &c.,

"A. B. Kennedy."

Great alarm has been felt in consequence of reports that the destructive scourge among cattle, the Tsetse fly, had made its appearance on the Natal frontier. We extract the following on this important subject: "It seems that for some time past there have been localities in Zululand where cattle could not live. The natives have accounted for this fact by assuming the grass to be in fault; but the real source of mischief is now ascertained to be the scourge of Central Africa—this fatal fly. As such an infliction was not observed until recently, it would almost appear as if this enemy of cattle flesh was extending its destructive operations to more southerly latitudes, but we are assured that it is only found along with large game, and in the more unoccupied situations. If this be really the case, Natal cattle farmers need entertain no apprehension." From the known habits of that fly, we do not think it will visit the great cattle pastures of Natal.'}, {'id': 117, 'article_title': 'RIVER ROVUMA, EAST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'RIVER ROVUMA, EAST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': '10-10-1862', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-24', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': '"We were on part of the slave route from Lake Nyassa to Quiloa (Kilwa), about thirty miles below the station of Ndonde, where that route crosses Rovuma, and a little further from the confluence of the Liende, which, arising from the hills on the east of the Lake Nyassa, flows into Rovuma. It is said to be very large, with reeds and aquatic plants growing in it, but at this time only ankle deep. It contains no rocks till near its sources on the mountains, and between it and the lake the distance is reported to require between two and three days. At the cataracts where we turned there is no rock on the shore, as on the Zambezi, at Kebrabasa, and Murchison's Cataracts. The

land is perfectly smooth, and, as far as we could see, the country presented the same flat appearance, with only a few detached hills. The Tsetse is met with all along the Rovuma, and the people have no cattle in consequence. They produce large quantities of oil yielding seeds, as the susame, or gerzelin, and have hives placed on the trees every few miles. We never saw ebony of equal size to what we met on this river; and as to its navigability, as the mark at which water stands for many months is three feet above what it is now, and it is now said to be a cubit lower than usual, I have no doubt that a vessel drawing when loaded about eighteen inches would run with ease during many months of the year. Should English trade be established on the Lake Nyassa, Englishmen will make this their outlet rather than pay dues to the Portuguese.

"We return to put our ship on Nyassa, by the Shiré, because there we have the friendship of all people, except that of the slave-hunters. Formerly, we found the Shiré people far more hostile than are the Makonde of Rovuma, but now they have confidence in us, and we in them. To leave them now would be to open the country for the slave-hunters to pursue their calling therein, and we should be obliged to go through the whole process of gaining a people's confidence again.

"If it may seem to some persons weak to feel a chord vibrating to the dust of her who rests on the banks of the Zambesi, and thinking that the path thereby is consecrated by her remains. We go back to Johanna and Zambesi in a few days. Kind regards to Lady M., and believe me ever affectionately yours,'}, {'id': 194, 'article_title': 'Gold Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Gold Coast', 'last_edit_date': '06-10-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_07_1863', 'content': 'Sir,—You wish a few samples of the fly, which I believe to be the "Tsetze." I am very much obliged for your kind offer, and send you by this mail, through our agents, Messrs. W. Hallalieu and Co., a bottle containing three different sorts of that fly—1, the so-called honey-fly; 2, the so-called beast-fly; 3, the common stinging fly. Of the first sort I could get but one specimen, as it is very rare. The third is the most common. The second I believe to be the "Tsetze," though I cannot decide it.

You would bestow a great favour upon our Gold Coast by submitting these samples to a competent person, to decide whether it is the "Tsetze" or not, as our committee have the intention of beginning a model farm, and if we have not the "Tsetze," the best place would be Abokobi. I would feel extremely obliged if you would be able to favour me with an answer with July mail, which is due at Accra on the 20th August.—My dear Sir, yours truly,  
CHARLES LOCHER.

*(From our own Correspondent.)*  
Accra, June 12, 1863.'}, {'id': 5201, 'article_title': 'Central African Exploration', 'full_section_title': 'Central African Exploration', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_09_1885', 'content': 'Particulars have lately been published of an expedition across Central Africa by Portuguese explorers, Captains Capello and Ivens, who journeyed from Mossamedes to the mouth of the Zambesi. A correspondent of the *Indépendance Belge* contributes additional details which show that the achievement is likely to rival in the display of courage and endurance, and also in importance, the journeys of Cameron, Stanley, and Serpa Pinto. The communication is accompanied by a map on which the route taken by the latest trans-African expedition is shown. This map generally confirms the surmises as to the course pursued by the explorers and the discoveries made. It does not show that any connexion between the waters of the Cobango, the river which flows southward from the neighbourhood of Bihé, and the Zambesi has been established. According to the map, Captains Capello and Ivens appear to have crossed the Cobango and proceeded across country until they struck the affluents of the Zambesi flowing through the Barotse-Mambunda country. They then crossed the watershed and entered the Congo basin. The hydrography of this portion of the country differs from the maps published by Stanley and other authorities. The southern portion of the Congo is represented as consisting of two great branches. One of these, the Lualaba, is shown flowing in a north-easterly direction from the Zambesi watershed through Lakes Lohemba and Kassali. The other great branch rises as the Chambesi in the high lands between the north end of Lake Nyassa and the southern extremity of Lake Tanganyika, and flowing down to Lake Bangweolo, is continued through Lake Moero and thence northward along the course of Stanley’s Livingstone. These two great arms may be spoken of, for distinction, as the Luapula and the Lualaba. In the main the hydrography thus described agrees with Stanley’s map, the difference being that the two systems are shown to continue separate up to the vicinity of Stanley Falls, instead of uniting far south of that point and immediately to the west of Tanganyika. It does not appear on what information this modification is based, as Capello and Ivens are not shown to have gone further north than Lake Moero. The total distance traversed by the explorers is stated to have been about 4,500 miles, and of this distance 3,000 miles were absolutely unknown territory. An interesting discovery made was that of the tsetse fly, or African mosquito. The disappearance of this pest from the south-east of Africa has been the subject of comment for a number of years past. The tsetse has generally been found in the vicinity of the elephant, and it has been assumed that it had migrated northward from south-east Africa with that animal. This hypothesis is confirmed by the fact that Captains Capello and Ivens met with large quantities of enormous elephants, and at the same time abundance of African mosquitoes, in the newly explored country through which they passed.'}, {'id': 6210, 'article_title': 'France and Dahomey', 'full_section_title': 'France and Dahomey', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-5', 'issue_date': '02_05_1892', 'content': '

We now pushed on south-west for the Umswezwi, from which good reports were coming in, and soon got into the country infested by the Tsetse fly. This fly, though not much bigger than an ordinary house-fly, is a veritable plague, for its bite is fatal to every kind of domestic animal, though to man and the game of the country it is innocuous. I found the prick of its probe, which will pierce the thickest hide, particularly irritating. We had to travel on foot in this thickly-wooded country, our food carried on donkeys, which, poor beasts, were condemned by the fly to an early death. There were many lions who only grumbled round the donkeys at night, but feared to spring, as I kept a lamp burning over their ears; I have, therefore, no thrilling adventures to relate. This was a grand mining country, and on all sides there was testimony of the amount of work that had been done by the ancients for the production of gold. Here tens of thousands of slaves must have been at work, and millions of tons have been overturned in their search for gold. A fact which points to the employment of forced labour is the crushing stones, the equivalents to our stamp-batteries. These stones are sometimes found in rows close to the mines, as if the poor creatures had been chained to their work. I have myself employed the natives to crush samples with similar stones, and you can see how little men could mill compared with a modern steam-driven stamp-battery. If, therefore, under those circumstances, the work was worth doing, how much more so with our modern appliances and ever-increasing need for gold. On the Mumbe River we carefully examined the Inez reef, on the hanging wall of which the ancients had done a vast amount of work, but had evidently found the quartz of the reef itself too hard for them. The prospectors had sunk three shafts of 30 feet each. The lode, which was a well-defined one, goes down at a uniform width of 5 feet 6 inches, and is identical in the various shafts from samples taken across the reef at this depth. It gave an average fire assay of 1 oz. 15 dwt., and milling 1 oz. 4 dwt., while 18 inches of it assayed as high as 5 ozs. Prospecting in this district has been rendered difficult by the number of old workings covering up the run of the reefs, and often the amateur prospector has been content to bribe the natives to show these old workings, and then pegged off claims on them irrespective of whether a reef was there or not. These men, finding they could not sell their claims at their own imaginative value, have come down country, saying Mashonaland is no good. It is simply laughable. After visiting many finds on the Umswezwi, which from surface indications were very favourable, we next visited the Mazoe, which we had been told on our arrival was a granitic country where reefs pinched out. A more lovely country it would be difficult to find. So rich is the soil that I believe anything would grow, and reliable accounts show that it is healthy. It is, too, a splendid mining country. Thus on arriving in the Tatagora valley we found a sandstone district to the West, with ironstone ranges to the East through a rocky gorge in which Mazoe flowed. We found here several splendid properties, about which the old practical miners were very sanguine.'}, {'id': 6513, 'article_title': 'The African Slave Trade', 'full_section_title': 'The African Slave Trade', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_12_1894#article-3', 'issue_date': '03_12_1894', 'content': "

Mr. Johnston, who commenced by pointing out how the nations of Egypt and Arabia in early times, observant of the muscular development and docile nature of the black man of Central Africa, had used him as a servant, and so had inaugurated the slave trade. This trade, once inaugurated, was carried on by the Egyptians, Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and Europeans down to the end of the last century, when the revival of human feeling urged certain philanthropists in England to move towards the abolition of a great evil. But during all this period the negro himself was as much to blame as the white and yellow men; indeed, it was probable that negroes were enslaving negroes long before Egyptian or Arab bought black servants from the negro chiefs, and at the present day there would be no slavery in Africa if an approval of slavery were not present in the philosophy of the negro tribes of Africa. Slavery and the slave trade, with the tribal wars and their attendant insecurity, had been the cause of Africa's backward condition, and if ever that Continent were to be raised to the civilisation of Europe, slavery and the slave trade must be extirpated. The two great slave markets which, until a few years ago, had existed in America, and in Turkey and Persia rendered the inducements to slave traders so great that the guarding of the coasts of Africa by British cruisers only checked the trade in a very slight degree; and even now many slaves were sent to Arabia, Persia, and Madagascar. In the present day, however, Africa was the main consumer of its own slaves. The most remarkable revival of the slave trade and occurred in German East Africa. The Germans, under Major Von Wissmann, began by suppressing a revolt of the Arab slave dealers, which led to the almost complete extinction of the oversea slave traffic on the German coast of East Africa; but the organisation of a strong government led to the rapid settling down of the Arabs as great landed proprietors, with an unlimited number of slaves to work their plantations. Legally slavery could not exist in German territory, but in such a wide and sparsely populated region it was impossible to prevent it in fact; and as the slaves were ordinarily well and kindly treated, it never occurred to them to want to leave their masters or to better their condition. It might be asked where, then, was the harm of slavery? The harm lay in this, that slavery commenced with an initial evil. The speaker then drew a picture of the loss of life, devastation of countries, and breaking of family ties which attended a capture of slaves. This depopulation of whole regions was attended with another evil, the return of the dreaded tsetse fly; and the surest way of extirpating this pest was to encourage population in the fertile districts of Central Africa. They must not expect much from the people themselves. The slave who once reached the East or West Coast was quite happy in his slavery; and, indeed, he would sooner proceed to an Arabian household or a Turkish harem than to the plain living of a Christian mission. As the nations of Europe realised the fact that the mere patrolling of..."}, {'id': 6740, 'article_title': 'Central African Exploration', 'full_section_title': 'Central African Exploration', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1896#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_05_1896', 'content': 'Regarding the future of the country, Dr. Moloney said: "It is rich in minerals, and owing to its altitude of from 3,000 to 4,000 feet is suitable for European occupation. Tsetse fly does not exist in Northern Rhodesia, and horses are therefore able to exist. The agricultural possibilities are highly favourable; the natives possess cattle in considerable numbers. Corn, potatoes, and ordinary vegetables are easily grown, and the conditions are favourable for the cultivation of coffee. The development of the country has already been commenced. The majority of my companions are still working there and commencing to develop the resources of the country.'}]

We found here several splendid properties, about which the old practical miners were very sanguine.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.651, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Future of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dr. Karl Peters, on March 5, delivered a lecture on "The Future of Africa," before a meeting of the Foreign Press Association, held at the Society of Arts, Adelphi, London. Dr. Peters said that there were to be found in Africa a number of cool and healthy high plateaux, where the white man could not only live in comfort, but where he found all conditions for agricultural and pastoral pursuits just as in his old country. There were large and mighty rivers, whose alluvial tracts made the cultivation of all kinds of tropical vegetation possible. There were not wanting direct inducements for immigration such as were offered to the white man\'s imagination by the existence of precious metals and precious stones, and a later generation of colonists would be able to use throughout the entire continent, from north to south, iron for their immediate wants, and in many districts coal required by modern industry. A modern traveller had truly said that "the greatest treasure of Africa consists in the inexhaustible labour force of its inhabitants." The Native population, which was estimated at about 200 millions, only required to be organised by the whites in order to raise the natural wealth of the continent. A sound connexion of justice with proper severity towards the blacks was the correct principle of conduct to act upon. Africa required railways and highways in every part for the purpose of its economic development and civilisation. Rinderpest must be exterminated. The whole African question was the question of communication, and in the solution of this question lay the conditio sine qua non of the future of the Dark Continent. A vote of thanks was passed to Dr. Peters at the conclusion of the lecture.', 'last_edit_date': '1897-03-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_04_1897#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GAMBIA BLUE BOOK.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**General Remarks.**—This settlement remained throughout the year gratefully free from any epidemic or contagious disease, although Freetown, the capital of the sister settlement of Sierra Leone, was subjected, in June, 1884, to the presence of what was alleged to have been yellow fever. The existence of cholera in the latter half of the year, in France, Italy and Spain, necessitated, in consequence of the shipping connexion, the enforcement against those countries of quarantine restrictions. The work of vaccination was resumed during the year with some success. Considerable sanitary improvement was effected in Bathurst by the supply of public latrines, erected over sites under the regular influence of the tide; there were also supplied public dustbins, which are daily emptied by sanitary carts, the contents being buried at the low swampy part of Half Die. An appreciated local exhibition in June of the Gambia contribution of woods and products for the International Edinburgh Wood Fair, 1884, for which a silver medal was awarded, was held in the Council Chamber of Government House, which I allowed to be used for the purpose. In an agricultural sense, comparatively little local encouragement in the past has been given by those who should be specially interested in the subject. Marketable articles, on presentation, are, perhaps, bought; but little or no interest on the part of those to whom it is of most immediate moment is directed towards the development of the resources of the country, by the practical enlightenment of the natives, from whom, in the circumstances, too much is expected, as to what may or may not be in their country of commercial value. The ground nut has stood pre-eminently now for many years as the commercial idol of the Gambia. Native marauding raids for the purposes of cattle lifting or slave catching, or uncertainty of tenure as regards alien states, townships, or villages, have affected and militated against the extent of its growth, while impoverished soil and disease have of late years affected its quality. Manuring is little or not at all resorted to, being cheaply and chiefly represented by occasional bush burning on sites to be cultivated. Natives are conservative, and are indisposed to change sites, which means trouble and increased labour. Everything is taken out of the ground, comparatively nothing is put into it. For instance, as regards ground nuts, both fruit, plant, and root are removed; the first for the oil or confectionery markets of America, the two last as horse or cattle food; and as to corn, the fruit is required for food, home consumption, or sale, and the stalk for fences, thatching, or mats. Of available dyes, and they are many, the indigenous indigo plants (there are two I know of here) offer a field for extensive growth that should prove, not only in the Gambia but on this coast, of much commercial success and monetary return. Crudely precipitated specimens from the Upper Niger, which I took to England in 1883, were pronounced as worth 4s. to 4s. 6d. per lb., and it was then alleged that the...', 'last_edit_date': '1885-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1885#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Commercial Outlook in the Congo Basin', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In view of increased interest in the Congo question, the vigorous resistance to any interference with the freedom of trade in those regions, and the feeling that the condition of trade makes the opening of new markets for the staple manufactures of this district a necessity, the Congo basin affords a suitable region for attempts to carry into effect the idea suggested at the annual meeting of the Manchester Guardian Trade Protection Society. One of the speakers suggested that as trade appears to be suffering from the fact that production exceeds consumption, it would be a good thing if capital was more systematically devoted to the work of distribution. We must conclude that some impulse to the distribution of wealth is needed; and a wider distribution of mercantile profits would doubtless be a consequence of the application of the joint-stock principle to mercantile enterprise.\n\nThere is a well-founded belief that the economic development of Africa will be a work of time, and that it is not at all likely to advance by "leaps and bounds." The fact is, that so far as the West Coast is concerned, experienced authorities have pointed out that the black man must be interested in cultivation if trade is to be permanent and African communities are to become large consumers of European manufactures. At the present rate of indiscriminate collection, the supplies of ivory must eventually be exhausted, the India-rubber and other plants be destroyed, and the whole country be converted into a waste. It is upon the interior that the interest of the trading and investing public is concentrated, because it is the region of untried possibilities. But the prudent ask whether, assuming the existence of vast stores of produce and favourable conditions of development and progress, markets can be found at paying prices for the produce which Central Africa may yield. It is a question of cost as well as of productiveness. African rivers are interrupted by cataracts from which the great rivers of other continents still only partially developed are free. It is true that the construction of railways is hinted at, but questions arise as to what will be the cost of such railways, who will provide the capital, how long before they become remunerative, and how many transhipments will be required; for it is conceivable that the mere cost of transporting produce to the consuming markets might prove greater than the price obtainable for them.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1885#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICA AND ITS TRADE POSSIBILITIES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Feb. 13, an interesting lecture, entitled "A Naturalist on the Mountains of the Moon," was delivered at the Royal Institution, Liverpool, under the auspices of the Liverpool Geographical Society, by Mr. G. F. Scott Elliot. The lecture was followed with much interest as an exposition from an authority on the subject. Mr. Scott Elliot, by his recent visit to Ruwenzori, has afforded additional information about this magnificent range of mountains in Central Africa, and his treatment of the subject was graphic and most informing. The address was made the more interesting by a series of limelight views. After touching on the character of Africa generally, the lecturer proceeded to give an account of the mountain Ruwenzori, the various difficulties in climbing the primeval forest, its inhabitants, the bamboo zone, the peat mosses, and the various tribes round the mountain. The occurrence of recent volcanic craters, and the manner in which the cloud hangs over the mountain all day long, only disappearing about sunset, was fully illustrated by slides from photographs taken by the lecturer. The lecturer described his experiences. Leopards attacked his camp, and very nearly killed two of his porters. A woman was carried off by a lioness, and he vainly attempted to rescue her. Elephants were extremely abundant round the mountain. The Natives were usually friendly, though the difficulty of obtaining supplies was often considerable, and on one occasion three of his men were attacked by them, and one very severely wounded. His march to the South was one of extraordinary difficulty, as his caravan consisted only of fourteen men, and the people were in places extremely unfriendly, and on one occasion attacked his porters. The future value of these little-known regions was shown by him to depend mainly on three factors—First, the natural wild resources, as rubber, palm oil, minerals, and ivory; secondly, the prospects of plantation by Europeans; and thirdly, the health of Europeans. The country between 3,000 and 5,000 feet had been proved to be valuable for plantations of coffee and tobacco. It is only in Africa above 5,000 feet that there is any possibility of a real colony being formed. The lecturer expressed his opinion that with the knowledge we have now of these parts, the Masai Highlands certainly appear to be quite healthy enough for Europeans to live and bring up children; but that so far there is no sufficient inducement for colonisation at present. Then, turning to the needs of Great Britain at the present time, he suggested that the three main requisites at present were—first, that our imports of food and raw material should come from our own Colonies; secondly, new markets; and thirdly, an outlet for our capital and population, both of which were unnaturally locked up in Great Britain. These new countries were, according to him, exactly adapted to answer those three urgent necessities.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1896#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Development of the Congo State', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Some interesting particulars of affairs on the Congo have been lately published, showing that, with the development of commerce on the great river, slavery is fast dying out. Boma and Matadi up the Congo, to which ports vessels from Liverpool are now plying direct, are becoming the chief ports from which produce is being shipped, and the facilities at these places are gradually drawing the ivory trade away from Zanzibar. On the upper reaches of the Congo, Tipoo Tib, who up till quite recently has been held up to execration as a slave-hunter, is now diverting the ivory which hitherto carried by slaves, was taken to Zanzibar and other ports on the East Coast. The Congo State has now its officials at the very spot where the Arabs collect the ivory. Instead of making raids on villages and killing hundreds of natives to obtain slaves to carry the ivory to the East Coast, the Arabs can now sell it to the Congo Free State at Stanley Falls, where a regular ivory market at present exists. The Arabs not requiring carriers have no need of slaves except for domestic purposes, and the terrible traffic is said to be gradually dying out. The road from the Upper Congo at Niangwe and from the Tanganika to the East Coast is a difficult one, and often ivory carried by slaves took one or two years to reach the coast by that route. In the neighbourhood of Stanley Falls the former slave-dealers are forcing themselves into a peaceful colony under Tipoo Tib, who has himself discarded his old slave raids and is employing his energies in ruling the people. It is the belief that the Tanganika-Zanzibar route will ere long be entirely superseded by the Congo route. This is the tendency at present, and when the Congo railway is completed the Congo route will be more availed of. Matadi can be reached by ocean steamers, and from Matadi, which is at the foot of the cataracts, the railway will start. Belgian, French, and Dutch houses are now established at Stanley Pool and are buying the ivory, which formerly found its way by caravans to the Angola Coast.\n\nA magnificent river, running parallel with and to the west of the Congo, has lately been discovered. The river, the Lomami by name, was found easily navigable and with a good depth. The Lomami will allow of the navigable Congo system being brought into direct communication with Niangwe, the chief Arab settlement on the High Congo, the Uangolle Lomami being only at a distance of three days' march from that town. The communication between Niangwe and Stanley Falls by the Congo is almost impossible, owing to the many falls and rapids; and the Lomami will form a further means of extending protection and bringing civilisation to regions which have suffered much from the Arab raids for slaves.", 'last_edit_date': '1889-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1889#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.641, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A CALL TO ACTION IN CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The value of Lancashire mill property has decreased one-half during the last three years. And the possessors of wealth must not suppose that the effect of such a decrease is merely local. It has already affected, and will affect, the whole country; and it is not too much to affirm that every possessor of property throughout the kingdom would act wisely in devoting a percentage of it to the forwarding of enterprises which, like that so luminously urged by Mr. Bradshaw, have aforetime brought new wealth and power into the land. There never was an axiom more true than that property has its duties as well as its rights. Let them reflect for a moment what their position will be a few years hence, when the population has risen, say, to forty millions, if no successful enterprise shall have opened extensive new marts for our manufactures, and developed the now dormant and unutilized resources of old ones. For this one thing is certain—the people will be fed. No argument will suffice to prove to millions of empty or only half-filled stomachs, that "sacredness of property," the belief in which can alone save property from destruction. The sooner this truth sinks into the minds of the possessors of property, and so influences their conduct as to urge them to exertion in the direction now pointed out, the better for them and for the country at large. The lately explored regions of Africa offer scope for an enterprise as glorious and as fruitful in wealth-giving results as that of the old East India Company, to which Great Britain is indebted for that richest of all her over-sea possessions. What has to be done must be done on a grand scale. Africa will never be civilized, to say nothing about its being Christianized, and its enormous resources developed and utilized, by dribblets of enterprise, which for the most part enfold within themselves the germs of inevitable failure. A great work can be only greatly performed. The industrial redemption of Africa, the bringing its large interior population into beneficial and permanent relation with European civilization, is a work worthy of the highest ambition to undertake and to accomplish. It is the duty, as well as for the interest, of the people of Great Britain to undertake it; and they will ere long bitterly repent if they persistently neglect a duty so imperative, so pressing, and so sacred.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1879#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.636, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Arabs on Lake Nyassa', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The serious part of the intelligence is the evidence which is afforded of the increasing audacity and violence of the Arab traders throughout Central Africa. The increase of Arab power in Central Africa, and enormous growth of slave-hunting and the slave traffic in consequence, are notorious. The German traveller, Lieut. Wissmann, found extensive districts depopulated and burned by the Arabs in the Kassai and Sankaru regions. Then there has been the attack on the Stanley Falls Station. The wave of reviving Arab power which has been spreading westward from the Zanzibar coast is now, it appears, spreading southward also. The first impulse to this extension is said to date from the end of 1883, when for a time our policy of armed intervention on the coast was changed. Every Arab on the coast appears to have regarded this change as an indication that our opposition to the trade had been abandoned. The recent agreement between Germany and Portugal for the division of the country as far as Nyassa, and the limitation of the Sultan of Zanzibar's influence to a coast-zone ten miles wide, have probably also stimulated the Sultan to endeavour to extend his influence to the west beyond the regions claimed by Germany. Arab camps are being placed at commanding points on the slave-routes, and Arabs visit and settle in the villages of the more powerful of the native chiefs. In short, there appears to be evidence that the disturbances on the Tanganyika and Nyassa, and it may be at Stanley Falls, are not due merely to the turbulence of isolated Arab ivory and slave hunters, but are parts of something like a concerted movement. The suggestion certainly seems to throw a new light on the action or inaction of Tippoo Tib at Stanley Falls, and on the appearance of Arabs west of the Aruwimi on the Welle-Makua.", 'last_edit_date': '1888-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1888#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.64, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'On the Climate and Diseases of West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"The sanitary condition of the town of Cape Coast, and indeed of all the towns upon the seaboard, is deplorable. Notwithstanding that some good has of late been effected by the municipality, yet, strange to relate, no public cloacinae have as yet been provided to meet the wants of the people, although the subject has been repeatedly taken up, and just as suddenly dropped, the consequence being that decency is constantly outraged, and the most disgusting nuisances are openly committed in the streets. Foul stenches everywhere assail the nose and corrupt the air, dunghills being attached to the huts, where garbage, filth, stinking fish, and other abominations are thrown. The smells along the byepaths and beach in the neighbourhood of the towns and villages are most offensive from accumulations of human ordure and offal; in fact, the native population is unrestrained by any police rules, except at Cape Coast and Accra. In both towns the municipal corporation have enacted laws for their conservancy; but in reality they are a dead letter, and hence an amount of nuisance scarcely credible. In the other towns, the Paynims, or native police, utterly neglect important matters of this kind. Indeed, the inhabitants of Cape Coast and the other towns and villages are chiefly indebted for their partial cleanliness to those useful scavengers, the turkey buzzards, largely helped by packs of half-starved, mangy curs and ill-conditioned hogs, who greedily devour the excrementitious matters which are left to rot upon the streets."', 'last_edit_date': '1863-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist\'s point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist\'s point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.629, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Suggestions for Destroying the Bug-A-Bug or White Ant', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—I have been told that British Combo would produce large crops of unequalled ground-nuts but for the ravages of the bug-a-bug, that fearful insect plague of Africa, the destruction caused by which is one of the hindrances to agricultural progress there. I believe that if some dry chloride of lime were thrown into or otherwise placed in the ants' nests, it would destroy all the inmates. I hope some of your African readers will try this on some white ants' nests near them, and watch, and communicate the results of the experiment to you.—Yours, &c.,", 'last_edit_date': '1866-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1866#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: British colonial neglect of sanitation and public health infrastructure in West African towns like Cape Coast resulted in widespread disease and unhealthy living conditions, endangering both local populations and European officials.
result: The observations from the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively underscore the claim that British colonial neglect of sanitation and public health infrastructure in West African towns, such as Cape Coast, led to widespread disease and unhealthy living conditions, affecting both local populations and European officials. The General History of Africa highlights the gross inadequacy and uneven distribution of colonial health services, which primarily benefited European settlers and administrators rather than the local African populations. It notes the significant disparity in healthcare access, exemplified by the situation in 1930s Nigeria, where there were only fifty-two hospitals for over 40 million Africans compared to twelve hospitals for 4,000 Europeans. While the textbook does not specifically mention Cape Coast, it provides a broader context of colonial neglect, with limited investment in health infrastructure and a focus on emergency measures against epidemics rather than comprehensive public health improvements. In contrast, The African Times articles provide detailed accounts of the deplorable sanitary conditions in Cape Coast, describing streets and public areas as dumping grounds for filth and excrement, leading to foul stenches and a pestilential atmosphere. The articles highlight the lack of public sanitation facilities, ineffective enforcement of municipal laws, and the prevalence of diseases such as smallpox, attributing these health crises to inadequate sanitary measures. They criticize British officials for their complacency and failure to implement necessary public health interventions, despite having the resources and authority to do so, and call for a change in governance and effective sanitary measures. Together, these sources provide a comprehensive view of the consequences of colonial neglect on public health in West African towns.

From 1840, when the first mission doctor arrived in Sierra Leone, there were across West Africa a scattering of medical missionaries including some Africans (mostly Sierra Leoneans). In 1924 Nigeria had a theoretical medical establishment of one doctor for every 200000 persons, but in fact only a quarter of these posts were filled. Five different types of educational institutions were established under colonial rule: primary, secondary, teacher-training, technical and university. [{'id': 166, 'article_title': 'On the Climate and Diseases of West Africa', 'full_section_title': 'On the Climate and Diseases of West Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-21', 'issue_date': '23_05_1863', 'content': '"The sanitary condition of the town of Cape Coast, and indeed of all the towns upon the seaboard, is deplorable. Notwithstanding that some good has of late been effected by the municipality, yet, strange to relate, no public cloacinae have as yet been provided to meet the wants of the people, although the subject has been repeatedly taken up, and just as suddenly dropped, the consequence being that decency is constantly outraged, and the most disgusting nuisances are openly committed in the streets. Foul stenches everywhere assail the nose and corrupt the air, dunghills being attached to the huts, where garbage, filth, stinking fish, and other abominations are thrown. The smells along the byepaths and beach in the neighbourhood of the towns and villages are most offensive from accumulations of human ordure and offal; in fact, the native population is unrestrained by any police rules, except at Cape Coast and Accra. In both towns the municipal corporation have enacted laws for their conservancy; but in reality they are a dead letter, and hence an amount of nuisance scarcely credible. In the other towns, the Paynims, or native police, utterly neglect important matters of this kind. Indeed, the inhabitants of Cape Coast and the other towns and villages are chiefly indebted for their partial cleanliness to those useful scavengers, the turkey buzzards, largely helped by packs of half-starved, mangy curs and ill-conditioned hogs, who greedily devour the excrementitious matters which are left to rot upon the streets."'}, {'id': 255, 'article_title': 'THE (COLONY OF THE) GOLD COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'THE (COLONY OF THE) GOLD COAST.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-21', 'issue_date': '23_11_1863', 'content': 'Is it to be wondered at that the moral education of the people progresses in a sense to be deplored instead of to be rejoiced at? Is it to be wondered at that the educated Africans are but too often slaveholders, when they see the European buying from their parents the half-educated girls of the mission schools (for these are the favourites), and abandoning both them and their mixed progeny when they no longer require their services.* What sort of moral progress can we expect among a shrewd, though debased people, when the conduct of those we send out to them preaches that the morality of England is for Englishmen in England only, and that the African system is best for Africa?

Nor is it only in a moral point of view that our rule in the Protected Territories fails, as it could never have failed, we think, had these been a colony. Fails we mean in all that this civilised Christian country ought to perform. Year after year, decade after decade, has gone by, and not a mile of road over which vehicles might pass has been opened into the interior; Cape Coast Castle even has remained dependent upon filthy tank water, filtered for officers and employés, and at this very time, at the close of the rainy season, the troops there are on half allowance of water; no attempt has been made to obtain water by boring, although the issuing of springs through the sea shore sands, and the proximity of the Kong Mountain range, render it certain that a good supply might be thus obtained; no effort has been made even to conduct the waters of the Sweet River to the town and fort, although seven miles of pipes would bring it from a point of some elevation. The town of Cape Coast is a mass of filth, pestiferous, fever-breeding, provoking dysentery; undrained, poisoning the air around, sending its vile exhalations up to the castle heights, although a few miles of open cutting (which the natives themselves are now attempting) would have given the population comparatively pure water in abundance, and afforded the means of washing away their abominations into the sea. Cesspools in towns are bad enough; but a town under a tropical sun, where every description of filth is deposited on the surface, wherever and wherever any individual may choose, and this town on the sea-shore, and with a river only a few miles distant, stamps the supreme authority there with indelible disgrace.

* We have often wondered whether the validity of these marriages, contracted according to the custom of the country, could not be established in our courts of law.—ED. A. T.
**56**'}, {'id': 2027, 'article_title': 'Horrible and Dangerous State of Cape Coast after Forty Years of British Rule', 'full_section_title': 'Horrible and Dangerous State of Cape Coast after Forty Years of British Rule', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1871#article-8', 'issue_date': '24_04_1871', 'content': "We have already endeavoured to direct the notice of the authorities to the abominable condition of the streets, lanes, and gutters of this town. We have no desire to trump up grievances, nor is it our wish to be for ever harping upon the same theme. But, in the interests of the entire public, we must again entreat those who have power to make some effort towards compelling people to deposit their dirt in some other places than the public thoroughfares. There is not the slightest exaggeration in saying that, for some time past, the town of Cape Coast, the head-quarters of Her Majesty's forts and settlements on the Gold Coast, has been one vast dunghill! We are all being actually poisoned by the foul atmosphere we breathe. A few days ago we tried to walk on the Anamaboe-road, but found it impossible to do so with safety to health; for upon that road, and within the precincts of this town, it would have been necessary to wade through thirty yards of sheer dung and minor garbage. An attempt has since been made to clean a part of this horrible and deadly accumulation, but not much good has been done. In various places in the very centre of Cape Coast, large masses of the most offensive matter render it really dangerous to pass by.

The health of the town is very bad in consequence of all this, and it is the opinion of experienced persons that we shall have some fatal pestilence before September.

We have written this article at the earnest request of several most respectable persons, native and European; and we have reason to hope that this appeal to his Excellency the Administrator will not have been made in vain."}, {'id': 2036, 'article_title': 'British Officials and Pestilential Filth', 'full_section_title': 'British Officials and Pestilential Filth', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1871#article-17', 'issue_date': '24_04_1871', 'content': 'A glance at our 112th page will convince the most incredulous that it is not only in the matter of gaol discipline and management that the extremely efficient and well-selected officials appointed by the Colonial-office to the West Coast of Africa show an entire absence of that "ordinary intelligence" which Mr. Knatchbull-Hugessen so desiderates for a proper comprehension of West African affairs. Any one not accustomed to the contemplation of West Coast enormities would imagine that, putting humanity altogether out of the question, the common instincts of self-preservation would stir up the European officials who are sent out to teach civilisation to the natives to insist upon the adoption and enforcement of those ordinary sanitary regulations which simple decency demands, and which are essential to the preservation of the public health even in temperate, and much more in tropical climates. Yet after forty years and more of British Government authority at Cape Coast, the state of the little town and neighbourhood is such as described. In the presence of so offensive, disgusting, and dangerous a state of affairs, are we not justified in becoming disturbers of official tranquillity? It is no doubt the summum bonum of official life to get as much pay, as many perquisites and indulgences, as much consideration and homage, and do as little work as possible; and it is perhaps an excess of impertinence to criticise the conduct of the favoured mortals sent of course expressly into the world to work out so delicious a destiny. But as a common every-day labourer in the vast field of humanity and progress, we have no sympathy with men who are content to enjoy their mistresses and drink their brandy and champagne upon a dungheap, provided they may occupy the highest position of the stinking mass. For after all, if this description be correct, as we know that it is, what are Government House or any other official abodes in the town of Cape Coast but the most elevated sites on a dangerous and offensive dungheap? The only man in office, so far as we remember, who ever made the slightest move toward doing anything for the purification of the streets and roads of Cape Coast Town was that blundering and arbitrary soldier Governor, Colonel Conran, whose one idea of governing was to bring every individual in the community under the provisions of the Mutiny Act. Our columns teemed years ago, before Colonel Conran's time, with denunciations of the public filth and indecency of Cape Coast Town, and of the British officials in power who made no effort to apply a remedy. And now of course, with the increase of population, things have gone from bad to worse. Shame and disgrace and infamy be upon successive governors and administrators, colonial surgeons and principal medical officers, who have attended only to their own selfish aims and enjoyments in the presence of the ever-augmenting abomination. We write with warmth; we have lately lost there a dear and cherished friend, who fell a victim to the pestilential atmosphere, and who, it may be, if governors and administrators had done their duty and made Cape Coast Town what it ought to be as a seat of British authority, might have been spared for yet many years of usefulness in the noble work to which she had dedicated the remainder of her existence. She had, it is true, mental anxieties, and a not over vigorous frame, but it was the pestilential fetor atmosphere of a tropical town full of all stinking abominations that killed her. And there is no excuse. There have now for a long time been abundant funds in the colonial chest—the British Administrator lives in the town—a governor-general goes, or ought to go, there occasionally—there is always one principal medical officer (army surgeon) as well as a colonial surgeon—there is (it is now some nine months or more since he was sent out) a Government civil engineer—and yet it seems that nothing effective has been attempted, and Cape Coast Town and its adjacent roads are one vast public privy and dunghill, upon which, as the Editor of the West African Herald justly observes, a general annihilating pestilence may, and most likely will, suddenly swoop down to carry off its thousands of victims. People who do not know what may be done by officials on the West Coast of Africa will perhaps say, "Oh, things cannot be so bad as that; the Administrator, &c., would certainly take care of himself, and he must incur the same danger there now as others." This is a great mistake. Let pestilence swoop down, as is but too reasonably anticipated, and the occupant of Government House, as well as other principal officials, would find no difficulty in obtaining leave of absence on urgent medical grounds. We can see no remedy, no efficient remedy, but a change, and a sweeping one, in the whole official system at Cape Coast. With continually augmenting revenues, soon we hope and believe to be doubled or trebled, no sanitary measures are adopted, no roads are planned, much less commenced; men may be flogged in gaol almost to the verge of death, and then sent to shot-drill to close their mouths for ever, and the Colonial-office sits still and looks on with contented self-complacency and admiration, and will, we fear, continue to look on, until the indignant thunderings of an outraged humanity shall make themselves heard from the mouth of some new Brougham amid the plaudits of an electrified House of Commons. Would to God that he may soon appear upon the colonially apathetic pool of the Imperial Legislature and impart a healing power to its waters!'}, {'id': 4490, 'article_title': 'Climate of West Africa—Gold Mining—The Labour Question', 'full_section_title': 'Climate of West Africa—Gold Mining—The Labour Question', 'last_edit_date': '08-05-1882', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1882#article-3', 'issue_date': '02_10_1882', 'content': 'It is a remarkable fact that the Spaniards, Portuguese, and Frenchmen who live on the Coast, and who, as a general rule, live far less liberally than do the residents who are natives of the United Kingdom or America, show a much larger sick list and a much higher death rate than the men of the Anglo-Saxon race. It is generally agreed that this is to be attributed to our superior mode of living, for the Spaniards, Portuguese, and Frenchmen are generally as hardy and as strong as we are.

The Chairman advised Europeans to adopt a diet of "rice, weak tea, and mild tobacco." Well, any white man who went in for such a diet should be either made of cast iron—if such a being could be manufactured—or else must be an idiotic candidate for a suicide's grave. Why, Kroomen cannot exist continually on rice; their diet has to be changed, in their own country, to corn, and, in factories down the Coast, to biscuit, with a free allowance of beef. A twelvemonth's diet of rice produces in most Kroomen valvular disease of the heart, with dropsy of the extremities and abdomen, and if the case is not treated at once, on the first signs of swelling in the feet, by change of diet, with medicine, death follows in a few days. Perhaps the Chairman can stand a diet that will kill a Krooman?

With regard to longevity of life in Africa, and the time a man can stay out without change of climate, much depends on where he resides. In Gambia, men have resided seven years at a time without leaving the place. On the Southwest Coast, men like Mr. Walker have resided three or more years without going to Europe or Madeira; while in the Bights three years is a long spell—eighteen months to two years being about the average time. Then a man, if he is even not very ill, feels the climate has so tried him that a few months' change to the north is absolutely necessary. The same rule applies to the Gold, Ivory, and Grain Coasts. But it is more than likely that on elevated ground, say fifty miles up the country, on these coasts, like the station of the Swiss Mission, near Ackra, that men could reside in very decent health for much longer periods, provided they have good food—fresh food, not tinned.

Half the mortality in the towns of the Gold Coast is caused by want of proper sanitation. Where every native yard is a private cemetery, where in such yards cesspools, years old, are the rule, and the ground is saturated with sewage, where water has to be stored in tanks, and is bad—how can the towns be healthy, under a tropical sun? With any quantity of land in the neigh

hood of such towns, there is no public cemetery for the natives. With the towns elevated above the sea, and washed by the surf of the Atlantic, there is no attempt at proper drainage, and the removal of sewage to the sea. The native prejudice as regards interments and dirt, must be respected, or the boasted liberty of the British subject would be infringed; and then a proper system of burial and drainage would cost money!'}, {'id': 4722, 'article_title': 'Great Britain: Her Colonies and Settlements', 'full_section_title': 'Great Britain: Her Colonies and Settlements', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1883#article-18', 'issue_date': '01_11_1883', 'content': 'introduction into at least the seats of government such as Cape Coast, Accra, and Lagos, of such sanitary measures as would remove from them their tropical and uncivilized unhealthiness. Very little, however, has been done in this direction; as the constant complaints from Lagos and Cape Coast, chronicled in their local journals, but too clearly establish. There is no blame lying at our door for this. Fifteen or more years ago we reproached one of the Governors as being satisfied to live on a dung-heap, if only he might follow his own vicious propensities; and the Governors may have become more moral, but they do not seem to have become more delicate. The public discussions in such a Colonial Representative Chamber sitting in London, as we have suggested, would soon lead to a change for the better in such important matters. There can be no reason why Accra, Cape Coast, Lagos, and other towns should not be made as healthy as Calcutta now is; Calcutta, than which no more fatally unhealthy place existed, when British rule was first established itself there. British West Africa, is, in a word, suffering under British contemptuous neglect, which the children of the present generation will deplore.'}, {'id': 5290, 'article_title': 'The Condition of the Gold Coast', 'full_section_title': 'The Condition of the Gold Coast', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1886#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_01_1886', 'content': 'If the thing described in the above extract were an isolated occurrence, I should not trouble you with it. The importance of it lies in the fact that it is merely an example of what is always going on. The people are allowed to grow up savage, there being only two Government schools in the country, and only two teachers (natives) in each. In the whole interior of the country there are but two police stations, and with these there are no police-courts. All the police magistrates are kept at the seaside to sit at receipt of custom. Outside the towns there are no roads, there are but three miles of telegraph. Yet the taxation is so heavy that, in 1883, the revenue came to nearly one-third the value of all the imports. ... Sanitation is as neglected as police and education; and a British colony is abandoned to ignorance, murder, and disease.—Your obedient servant,  
E. Eiloart.  
Temple, December 24.

---'}]
