One of my trustworthy correspondents at Bathurst thus writes:—

"The angel of death has been with us—paid us a long visit—exacted a heavy tribute of victims, and left his mark indelibly stamped on this unfortunate town.

"Mr. Carr, the Chief Magistrate, four Europeans, and three natives were swept off in one day.

"It is a fearful sight to walk through Bathurst; nearly every one is in mourning, even the poorest of the natives. Death has touched all.

"There is a large surplus—several thousand pounds—in the treasury."

There seems every reason to believe that a liberal planting of Eucalyptus globulosa trees would, within a very few years, effect much of what is needed for health, and convert the fatal climate of Bathurst into a salubrious one.

The French Government are said to have planted above 2,000,000 Eucalyptus globulosa trees in the malarious swampy districts of Algeria, and the results are reported to have been most satisfactory.

Under these distressing circumstances, I take the liberty to call upon Her Majesty's Government, in the name and on the part of the suffering residents at Bathurst, both native and European, to order and direct that, in addition to those engineering measures which the local authorities have most shamefully neglected, sufficient planting of Eucalyptus globulosa trees in and about these poisonous swamps, so fatal to the public health, should be immediately ordered and effected.—I have the honour to remain, Sir, yours respectfully,  
F. FITZGERALD, Editor of the _African Times_.

To Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, M.P.,

Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies.'}, {'id': 3721, 'article_title': 'THE FEVER AT BATHURST', 'full_section_title': 'THE FEVER AT BATHURST', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1879#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_02_1879', 'content': 'Weeping and mourning are at the Gambia; desolation and woe have fallen upon the unhappy town of Bathurst. A pestilential fever, against the threatened approaches of which no efforts at prevention were made by ignorant, incapable, and criminally erring officials, marched up from the foetid swamp, descended into the habitations of rich and poor, European and native; and death, terror, and dismay reigned supreme over all. The graphic letter on our 2nd page tells a little of the fatal tale. The Chief Magistrate, a young man in the full vigour and strength of life, four Europeans, and three natives, fell victims in one day. Well might the poor stricken people believe that this was only the vanguard of the Yellow Fever which had made its ravages at Senegal; and against the probable coming of which we had warned the besotted officials, who were too intent, each on his own little game, to heed our earnest entreaties to set their house in order. A heavy responsibility for the precious lives that have been taken away, should lie at the door of those whose duty it was to take adequate measures for the preservation of the public health. The large surplus which is the present boast of the Gambia Treasury—to create which the public service has in many ways been starved, and for creating which personal promotion is no doubt expected—is now made loathsome by the putrid corpses of victims whose lives have been sacrificed to it. Cynics and profound moralists equally affirm, that at the present time nothing is worshipped but money. The officials of Gambia and Sierra Leone may be adduced in support of the truth of this stigma. We earnestly hope the results will not be as fatal in the latter place as in the former. But when blundering, incapacity, and selfishness had done their worst, a kind Providence stepped in with its healthy Harmattan wind, and the pestilence gradually abated. We hope the influence of that health-giving wind will be felt at other parts of the Coast. Its absence last year was deeply deplored at Lagos, where small-pox and other fatal diseases then prevailed. But although the pestilence has been killed for a time at Bathurst by the Harmattan, we hope the present safety will not renew the guilty official apathy; and that the lives of the inhabitants will be deemed of more value than a few hundreds of pounds, more or less, in the Treasury. We say advisedly, guilty official apathy. Look at paragraphs in a letter from Bathurst in our last month's paper, page 2: "The streets and drains are very dirty, the effluvia from the latter very bad; the native yards in a filthy state; and though we pay local rates of 400l. a year, and there is a surplus now in the Treasury of 6,000l., yet not a penny can or will be spared for sanitary measures, because Mr. Bauer" (the Colonial Engineer) "will not act;" and yet we are face to face with a most sickly season; fever fast approaching to an epidemic in virulence; deaths are rapid and numerous, natives as well as Europeans. Still nothing is done!" Our correspondent goes on to say that some months ago, "We sent a petition to the Colonial Secretary, complaining of the inefficiency of the Engineer Department, asked for a Board of Inquiry, and engaged to substantiate all our charges. In other words, the memorialists of Bathurst had the lie given to them, in the same way that it was also given to those of Sierra Leone; in both cases upon the mere ipse dixit of the erring Governor. ### TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Bathurst, R.G., February 4, 1879.

Sir,—The war in Baddiboo still goes on. Biram Sesay has pushed his forces to within twelve miles of the British frontiers in Burra, has taken Kutchan, and a town ten miles below that. The war is rapidly becoming one of plunder and murder. All men fit to bear arms are either beheaded or ripped up; women and children are sold as slaves. Molo, King of Jarra, threatens to join Biram, and so completely crush Mamoud Dari Bah. Still no attempt is made by the authorities at Sierra Leone to send even a man-of-war to help us. The French merchants here have written to Senegal for one of their own men-of-war to come and protect their interests. This is the second time the French here have had to do this within a few years. Here the "Civis Romanus" principle is absent.

In your issue of January 1st you speak of the late fever here not being epidemic. It certainly was epidemic; but the Government officials dared not recognize the fact, for fear the steamers would stop calling here. Putrid fever and some cases of yellow fever did occur. The rest of the cases of fever were of a bad, low, and virulent type; and if the doctors were to speak out, they would acknowledge this. The late rainy season was the most sickly we have had in Gambia for years, though not near so bad as in Senegal; but that it was bad enough God knows, and the cemetery can testify.'}, {'id': 4176, 'article_title': 'The Menace of War by Ashanti', 'full_section_title': 'The Menace of War by Ashanti', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_03_1881', 'content': "

That virulent small-pox should be carrying off daily its ten or a dozen victims from among the small native population of Bathurst, or that any other fatal epidemic should be committing its ravages there, ought not to be a matter of surprise with any one who had read the accounts we have given from time to time, and very recently with added emphasis, of the infamous absence of all adequate sanitary regulations for making the place a safe habitation for human beings, whether white or black. We have, as our readers well know, felt the most serious apprehensions that the yellow fever, which had visited Senegal, would descend to Bathurst, as offering a most tempting field for it to revel in. Happily, however, according to latest advices, it seems to have spent its energies at St. Louis, and has died out there. But we were not surprised to hear that while the yellow fever was at the Senegal, a virulent smallpox should have broken out among the natives at Bathurst, it having been almost invariably the case that whenever yellow fever made its appearance among the Europeans on that part of the Coast, there should be a great mortality from small-pox among the natives, who do not suffer from yellow fever, as neither do the Europeans from the native small-pox. In a letter from the Gambia which we insert in this present number, it will be seen that the Secretary of State for the Colonies had instructed Sir Samuel Rowe to call at the Gambia on his passage down the West Coast, to inquire into the great neglect and abuses of which we have so often and so vehemently complained. Unfortunately, owing to the pressure of the scare at Cape Coast, Sir Samuel will not have been able to make that visit and inquiry. We are very sorry that this is the case; but, nevertheless, we do venture to hope that the mere fact of such a visit and inquiry having been ordered by the Colonial Office will impel the authorities to make extraordinary efforts to set their house in sanitary order, and that we shall not have again to complain of a state of the burial-ground, the drains, and the general absence of sanitary regulations, such as we have had the painful duty so often to expose and comment upon. The strange neglect by British authorities in almost all the Coast towns of ordinary means to purify the atmosphere is a great disgrace to us as a nation. What has been done at Calcutta, in the East Indies, once as unhealthy a residence for Europeans as any one of the West Coast towns, might long ago have been done in these also. We would ask our readers to glance for a moment at the complaints about the state of Quittah, where a considerable revenue is already raised, and where a much larger one might, it is stated, be raised by a modified scale of Customs' duties, such as would put an end to the temptation of smuggling from the neighbouring sea-coast villages without British jurisdiction. Disgraceful is a word scarcely strong enough to apply to such a state of things. It is a lamentable fact that, so far as the Government is concerned, we do not carry civilization and civilizing efforts with us. Our officers are content to sit upon dung-heaps, surrounded by the most atmospheric-poisoning filth, to collect their Customs' duties; and then we complain of the fatal atmospheric impurities of so many of the sea-coast towns. Is it too much to hope that the new Governor-in-Chief of the Gold Coast Colony will find some remedy for this fearful state of things? As a medical man, we hope that he will prove to be sensitive in this matter. We feel that he has Herculean tasks before him. His predecessors have done so little that there is overwhelming work for him to do, unless he be allowed to appoint subordinates whom he can imbue with his own spirit. We would venture to ask his Excellency's consideration of our Quittah letters. They are brief and plain, but to the point, and, we think, well worthy his attention, so soon as his settlement of the Ashanti episode and the important Lagos question referred to in our last will permit. Bathurst, River Gambia, August 30th, 1881.

Sir,—Though to-day is the twentieth day since the water broke through the embankment at Half Dic, yet the repairs are not finished. Since my letter on the 17th inst. there have been some more stones added in the centre of the gap, and some mud at each end; but the opening is not as yet filled up to the level of the embankment. The last two flood-tides came through. The rains are still on, heavy. The tides are rising springs; so the place may be broken again, and Half Dic again under water.

I have just returned from there; the streets in that portion of the town are studded with stagnant pools, connected by what was, years ago, meant for drains; each pool with a green scum on the top, and a few inches of black mud at the bottom. Stir the contents up, and a stench rises like a well decomposed cesspool; now expose that to a hot sun, such as we have every day, when it is not raining, and you have most fruitful germs of malarious fever. The carelessness of the authorities about the broken embankment at Half Dic, and the filth of the streets there, is incredible.

Yet while such a state of things exists, the Colonial Engineer and Sanitary Inspector plays the rôle of Collector and Treasurer at the Custom House. His Excellency the Administrator, we may suppose, approves; he gives no sign to the contrary, anyhow; and the inhabitants suffer and s—. Well, I mean they don't bless.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

FREDERIC SPEER.

---

A MERCHANT'S VIEW OF THE GAMBIA RIVER TRADE.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Bathurst, Gambia, July 27th, 1881."}, {'id': 4302, 'article_title': 'AN EPIDEMIC SEASON', 'full_section_title': 'AN EPIDEMIC SEASON', 'last_edit_date': '10-02-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1881#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_10_1881', 'content': 'PARIS, 2nd October.—The Union Médicale draws attention to the various epidemics which now prevail in different parts of the world, and with regard to which it gives us some important but unpleasant details. It says that cholera is spreading in the East, and advancing towards Europe. It has already made considerable ravages at Aden, and has reached Mecca, where the Mussulmans are imploring their Prophet. The professional journal reminds us that Aden and Mecca are the two points of the world the most adapted for the propagation of any disease. Almost all ships from the East stop at Aden on returning to Europe; while in respect to the Mahometans of Mecca, although few of them come to Europe, still they go almost everywhere else. Great care and inspection are therefore necessary. Happily, the International Sanitary Commission have directed their attention to the progress of the epidemic.

Two other epidemics continue to spread death around them. The first is the yellow fever in Senegal, where the number of victims has been great, but the Union Médicale says that terrible malady does not propagate in Western climates. The same thing, however, cannot be said of the second disease, diphtheria, which has killed more people in the south of Russia than any epidemic, not excepting the plague. It has prevailed there ever since 1872, and has never ceased to spread. In Bessarabia 15,000 out of 36,000 persons who were attacked have succumbed to it in the district of Pultawa. Out of 46,000 cases 19,000 ended fatally, and in Kharkoff, out of 29,000 cases there have been 17,000 deaths. I may add that in Paris just now diarrhœa is extremely prevalent.'}, {'id': 4332, 'article_title': 'Official Delinquencies', 'full_section_title': 'Official Delinquencies', 'last_edit_date': '10-25-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1881#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_12_1881', 'content': 'Sir,—About ten months ago small-pox was raging here, and the number of deaths was very large, so the local Government had to appoint an Acting-Assistant Colonial Surgeon to specially look after the small-pox cases, and supervise vaccination. Dr. Taylor, of Sierra Leone, was offered the appointment and accepted it, and fulfilled his duties to the satisfaction of everyone. But a jealous feeling towards that gentleman, on the part of certain of the leading officials, caused an application to be sent to the Colonial Office to send out a doctor from England, and in due time Dr. W. Allan arrived here, and superseded Dr. Taylor, who afterwards left the Colony in disgust. Well, small-pox died away, and Bathurst became healthy; then the Senior Colonial Surgeon, Dr. Spilsbury, went to England on leave of absence, leaving Dr. Allan to perform his duties and look after his private practice (which is a lucrative one) among the European houses. Previous to Dr. Spilsbury going on leave, Captain Roche, the First Writer, or, as he is called here, "the Governor's Secretary," went on leave; and for a time His Excellency managed to do without a "Secretary." But finding this inconvenient, he asked the Chief Clerk at Government House to undertake the duties; and he refused unless he was paid an extra salary—and quite right, too. The Governor then applied to Dr. Allan to take the post, and he accepted it. The consequence is that now his whole day is taken up with his quill-driving duties in the office in Government House, and he has little time to attend to his duties as medical officer; so his patients have to suffer. He tells his patients he has not got time to visit them; that "If he got ten dollars a visit he could not come to them;" that "if he had them all at the Colonial Hospital he might manage to look after them" (i.e., give the dispenser instructions, and leave him to do the best he could), "but he cannot undertake to attend them properly now, as he is the greater part of the day at Government House." Bathurst has been for the past three months rather sickly, particularly among the native folk; and yellow fever, which has decimated the population of St. Louis, Senegal, the deaths being nearly 600, is now bad at Goree; and'}, {'id': 4672, 'article_title': "Lamplough's Pyretic Saline", 'full_section_title': "Lamplough's Pyretic Saline", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1883#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_08_1883', 'content': 'We are experiencing a certain amount of disturbance through the reports of destroying epidemics, and the precautions which those reports necessarily induce. The cholera (Asiatic or other), which has been causing so many deaths in Damietta, Cairo, and other towns and districts of Egypt, has caused also considerable inquietude throughout Europe, and called anew into being those quarantine laws an exaggerated enforcement of which produces no small amount of individual suffering, without corresponding general advantage. While the cholera (Asiatic or other) is making its ravages in Egypt, and creating a panic in Mediterranean countries, the old enemy of the tropics, the yellow fever, has been equally fatal at Vera Cruz, and other portions of the coast, in the Gulf of Mexico; and we cannot forget that on former occasions, when this dreaded malady has been thus prevalent on the Mexican Gulf shores, it has also made its destructive visit to some of the countries of the West Coast of Africa. Whether this has been through contagion by contact, or through analogous conditions of climate, seems to be uncertain. But be it which it may, the fact of the epidemic being in vigour at Vera Cruz draws our thoughts at once to Bathurst and Sierra Leone, in the former of which places the state of the drains, burial-grounds, &c., is such as to offer special invitation to yellow fever, or any other destructive malady. It is not in our power, nor within our province, to put an end to such atrocious and suicidal neglect, which has been so often exposed and animadverted upon in our columns; but we feel we should be wanting in our duty if we did not anew remind our readers of the peculiar and wonderful efficacy of **LAMPLOUGH'S PYRETIC SALINE.** It is now some twenty years since, at the instance of General (then Colonel) Hill, who vouched for its wonderful efficacy and preservative powers, as [experienced by himself during his residence in West Africa as Governor at Sierra Leone, the West Coast, through our columns, became acquainted with it, and its merits were widely acknowledged. The **African Times** was then the only journal of and for the West Coast, and it refused to advertise any other medicine; and even **LAMPLOUGH'S PYRETIC SALINE** was not advertised without full inquiry into its merits beyond the experience of Governor Hill. Nothing could be more satisfactory than the facts elicited in that inquiry. Its discovery was owing to researches and experiments made by Dr. Stevens in the Danish West India Island of St. Thomas. There had been most severe epidemics of yellow fever in the island; the mortality was something like seventy out of every hundred attacked. Dr. Stevens, not satisfied with the medical treatment under which the number of fatal cases was so appalling, entered upon a scientific study of the disease. He found, on examination, that in the blood taken from yellow fever patients whose attacks proved fatal, there were no globules; that the effect of the disease was to break down the globules in the blood, converting it into a thick fluid, no longer capable of sustaining life. He subjected this blood to a series of experiments, and at last succeeded by a combination of salts, &c., in reproducing globules in that blood. On this he based his treatment, and reduced the mortality during the next visit of the epidemic to less than 5 per cent. In recognition of services so eminent, His Majesty the King of Denmark bestowed on him a considerable estate, which he enjoyed until two or three years since, when he died of very advanced age at Cheltenham. **LAMPLOUGH'S PYRETIC SALINE** is the combination with which Dr. Stevens cured his yellow fever patients, and with which also he treated some 250 cholera patients in Coldbath-fields Prison, London, during the Asiatic cholera epidemic of 1866. **LAMPLOUGH'S PYRETIC SALINE** is, therefore, not a mere agreeable effervescing aperient, as are, without exception, we believe, the numerous effervescing salines which have sprung into existence as imitations, being for the most part only carbonate of soda, Epsom salts, and tartaric acid, which latter, being prepared from "argols," or the crystals deposited in wine vats, may, indeed, with propriety, be termed a fruit salt, but which as such has no property beyond that of impelling the carbonate of soda to effervescence. We have thought it right at this time, when yellow fever may be threatening the West Coast of Africa, and cholera be threatening England, to remind our readers of the essential difference between **LAMPLOUGH'S PYRETIC SALINE** and the host of effervescing imitations which have more or less succeeded in profiting by its fame, and thus getting into consumption. **LAMPLOUGH'S PYRETIC—DR. STEVENS' COMPOUND**—exercises a direct and decided regenerating and revivifying action on the blood beyond the indirect action of the other aperient salines; and as we have done from time to time during the past twenty years, so again we recommend it to the daily use of our readers, whether on the West Coast of Africa or in England.'}, {'id': 5276, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA BLUE BOOK.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA BLUE BOOK.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1885#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_12_1885', 'content': '

The earthy matter which my specimen contained could be eliminated in the manufacture, the indigo dye would be worth more, and might, perhaps, rival Bengal. The Gambia Settlement is flanked on either side by countries exporting gum largely, and yet, odd as it may seem, this article has not so far ranked among the exports from this grand river. Although those interested commercially have endeavoured to convince me to the contrary, I have personally made it my business to look into the matter, and have succeeded in assuring myself, by specimen proof, of the local existence of the same gum as is exported annually by millions of pounds weight from the adjacent colony of Senegal. Indigenous in Fouta D'jalon, which is laved by the Upper Gambia, is coffee, which, originally from that source, has now by dint of energy, speculation, and cultivation become an article of export from the rivers that lie between this colony and Sierra Leone; yet coffee has never been put thence on the market. Beniseed, corn, and rice might be luxuriantly grown and developed in an agricultural sense to a sufficiency not only for home consumption, but also for profitable export. The "Gofio" eating people of the Canaries and Cape Verde Islands present a near and fixed market for Indian corn, of which there might be obtained here two crops a year. There is much room both as to space and adaptability of soil for the extensive growth of the oil palm, the cocoanut palm, the castor oil, and cotton plants. The turqueira (physic) nut is to be found here—though not extensively, yet in luxuriant form. Much attention is now given to its growth in the adjoining Cape Verde Islands. Some years ago the Gambia was well represented in the European timber markets; it yet offers a field rich in its celebrated mahogany, rosewood, ebony, runs, &c. The last mentioned thrives better in water than out of it, and would answer for foundations of buildings in Holland. The local rubber industry began to develop in 1882, and by the extension of proper instructions in modes of collection, as also in the establishment of a proper knowledge of the value of the vines, so as to avoid their wholesale destruction, has room for much increase. Unfortunately here, as elsewhere in the collection of rubber, it is a regular case, I fear, of killing the goose for the golden egg. The value of the exports in this commodity in 1883 was £6,047, and in 1884, £23,213. For a local trade, especially in tomatoes—so largely consumed by the Wolofs of these parts—kitchen gardening might be promoted with considerable pecuniary advantage, much more so than is the case. Results have proved that cabbages, tomatoes, lettuce, beetroot, parsley, watercress, pumpkins, melons, pine apples, guavas, bananas, mangoes, even European strawberries, as fine as could be desired, may be grown here during certain months of the year. Under "Mail Service" I remarked upon the means existing for telegraphic communication with Europe. Direct telegraphic communication hence with Europe, either by means of the laying of a cable between Dakar and Bathurst, seventy or eighty miles, or by the extension of the Senegal land wire (fifty miles), or by the continuation of the cable European connexion with St. Vincent (270 or 280 miles), Cape Verde Islands; a more liberal and convenient mail service both with England and Sierra Leone; a lowering of the English freight tariff, so as to admit of more direct and full import of English goods; the lighting up of the sea approach and entry to the Gambia; a new Government wharf or landing stage, laid with tramways, of sufficient size to accommodate at one time two average-sized steamers for the centralization and expedition of the local import and export trade; rapid means of personal locomotion by tramcar to Cape St. Mary, the health resort of this capital, now more than ever that the Oyster Creek Bridge has been finished; reclamation of and filling in of swampy land adjoining Bathurst; a new Court House; extended gaol accommodation; road and street improvements; a public library, and an improved water-supply,—represent wants of much moment to the development of this settlement, which, it is to be hoped, may gradually come at no distant date within the sphere of practicable and visible improvements. Again, there are no such institutions as contagious diseases hospital and poor-house, but the consideration of their supply has not escaped the attention of the Government.'}]

Notwithstanding that some good has of late been effected by the municipality, yet, strange to relate, no public cloacinae have as yet been provided to meet the wants of the people, although the subject has been repeatedly taken up, and just as suddenly dropped, the consequence being that decency is constantly outraged, and the most disgusting nuisances are openly committed in the streets. The smells along the byepaths and beach in the neighbourhood of the towns and villages are most offensive from accumulations of human ordure and offal; in fact, the native population is unrestrained by any police rules, except at Cape Coast and Accra. In the other towns, the Paynims, or native police, utterly neglect important matters of this kind. Indeed, the inhabitants of Cape Coast and the other towns and villages are chiefly indebted for their partial cleanliness to those useful scavengers, the turkey buzzards, largely helped by packs of half-starved, mangy curs and ill-conditioned hogs, who greedily devour the excrementitious matters which are left to rot upon the streets."', 'last_edit_date': '1863-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.707, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Yellow Fever at St. Louis, Senegal', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following was read in the French Legislative Chamber on the 21st December, and produced a great sensation there: "St. Louis, Senegal, December 7, 1880.—Sir,—Yellow fever has broken out in our colony. I have myself paid my tribute to the malady, from which I have just recovered. Fortunately, the attack was slight. Nevertheless, my health is quite broken down, and convalescence, I fear, will be tedious. Therefore I ask of the Chamber an indefinite congé, which will enable me to stay until strength returns, and to see the last of the epidemic.—Signed, Gasconi."

On the following day this Reuter's telegram appeared in the English papers: "A private cablegram received by a Liverpool firm this morning intimates that an outbreak of yellow fever has occurred at St. Louis, Senegal. A quarantine of four days has been ordered for vessels arriving in the Gambia from Goree. Both St. Louis and Goree are French ports."

There seems, therefore, no room for doubt that this destructive epidemic has again visited the West Coast of Africa; and we can only hope that it will not descend from the Senegal to the Gambia, where an utter, and we may justly term it infamous, neglect of the most ordinary sanitary arrangements seems especially to invite it.—Ed. My Lord,—In the editorial article in the Lancet of October 13, page 442, we find the remark that "it is a singular fact in medical geography that from St. Louis, Senegal, on the north, to Mossamedes, on the south, there is not upon the seaboard a single healthy acre of ground. It is well known that in all diseases the great restorative agent is pure air, and this is obtained on lofty ranges, along the seacoast, or elsewhere, inaccessible to the influence of malaria. This fact has been established in India beyond all doubt, and extensively acted upon, irrespective of expense, it being known that life is sure to be saved by it. In the West Indies the same sanitary measure has been taken, in the formation of a camp, at a

New Castle, the attitude of which defies the approach of the most pestilential lithoral poison.

But it appears that, until lately, there has been scarcely any knowledge amongst Englishmen that the West Coast of Africa is garrisoned by British soldiers, whose lives are as precious as any other soldiers, and who go heartily to fight for their sovereign against, not only barbarous tribes, but also against the pestiferous, ghastly miasma that poisons the atmosphere of many parts of this Coast. This was abundantly proved in the late disastrous expedition against the King of Ashantee, where men and officers died without number, and without even seeing an enemy. There has been a great neglect respecting the requirements of the West Coast of Africa, and even a simple account of the Coast, in these enlightened days, is received with the same wonder and surprise as the adventures of Mungo Park and Robinson Crusoe. So little, indeed, is known of it, that in print, in public speeches, and in private conversation, it is termed the most unhealthy region in the world; yet still if one takes the percentage of deaths amongst the different stations of the British Army, irrespective of the great sanitary measures used by the Government, it will be found that many of them were by far more unhealthy than the West Coast of Africa. The African Times has always endeavoured to point this out; and as a proof of it, I may state that some time ago, so great and so frequent was the amount of havoc committed on the soldiers quartered in one of the West Indian Islands by disease, that all but one officer were laid hors de combat, so that the troops were entirely withdrawn, and a notice was sent to the colonial authorities that, should they intend to keep the island, they were to increase their police force.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-12-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.717, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Fatal Epidemic at Senegal', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'By letters from Bathurst we are informed that the epidemic at Senegal is very terrible, the latest advices from thence reporting over 600 deaths.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1879#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The (Colony of the)', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'This position altogether is so far clear. But we have been subject to such misrepresentations when combating stereotyped misstatements as regards West Africa, that we will not allow any one to misunderstand us. The opinions we put forward with regard to the climate of West Africa have not been hastily or crudely formed, nor have they been adopted to serve some temporary or interested purpose. They are the result of evidence that cannot be disproved. They are promulgated by us to remove prejudices which war against our efforts for the advancement of civilization in Africa, and because we feel that they are pregnant with most practical results. We do not, for instance, pretend that the West African climate is not unhealthy. We admit that it is. But we as fearlessly contend that it is not one whit more unhealthy for Europeans than many of the West India Islands, or than Hong Kong, China, or India, &c. These regions are equally liable to visitations of epidemic disease as is West Africa, in the shape of yellow fever, dysentery, &c. We are, moreover, firmly convinced that if ever the day arrives when complete, and not mere partial statistical tables, are compiled, showing the mortality amongst Europeans at the Gambia, Sierra Leone, the Gold Coast, and even the new settlement at Lagos, the facts fairly and impartially revealed will demonstrate that at least a moiety of the deaths which occur amongst them are not the result of climatic disease, but are chargeable occasionally to accident; more frequently to a lamentable and wanton neglect of ordinary care and precautions; and too often to reckless indulgences, which will in any climate sap the springs of life, and ultimately destroy it. As additional evidences in support of these statements, take, for example, the records with regard to the numerous governors who have served, or are now serving, in West Africa. We find that in most instances they were and are men who had passed middle life before being called upon to administer those Governments, and were consequently far less able to bear up against attacks of fever. Yet, of the thirty-four gentlemen who have governed Sierra Leone from 1792 to 1864, seven only died there in that long period of seventy-two years. Of those seven, one was killed in action, another veteran most unwisely made fruit and vegetables his sole diet; and one of them had previously lived upwards of thirty-five years in the colony, dying at sea, not of disease incident to the climate, but of cancer of the stomach. [January 23, 1864.]', 'last_edit_date': '1864-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.686, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Lamentable Deaths of European Officials on the West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—I read the paragraph in your paper of this month under the above title, and can add my testimony to the value of “Lamplough’s Pyretic Saline,” if not as a sure preventive, certainly as a deterrent and palliative in African fevers.

In your remarks, however, I find no mention made of the probable causes of such mortality, which I think is necessary when speaking of the effects of a climate like West Africa, the bad reputation of which is so very much exaggerated. Nor do you make any distinction between the colonies, classing Sierra Leone with Lagos, Gambia, and Cape Coast, which I am sure the facts would not warrant.

To revert, however, to the causes of mortality on the West Coast of Africa, I am of opinion that there are many influential causes conducing to the same which might be prevented, and I take the liberty of intruding on your valuable space to enumerate one or two of them.

1. The large consumption of spirituous liquors (brandy, gin, &c.) by the Europeans, Englishmen in particular, beginning from the moment they are out of bed till the last thing at night, when they have frequently to be put to bed by their friends or servants, is not calculated to improve even a strong constitution in the best of climates, much less one already broken by excesses. That a disproportionately large number of Europeans on the West Coast of Africa are very much addicted to the excessive use of strong liquors cannot be wondered at if you take into consideration the class of men who venture on that Coast, notwithstanding its bad reputation, and for a pittance which a junior clerk here would reject with contempt.

Compare with Sierra Leone, where I resided for eleven years without interruption, South America, Brazil in particular, where an epidemic of yellow fever is of yearly occurrence. The salaries of clerks in Rio de Janeiro, Bahia, Pernambuco, and other ports are not less than 200l. to 250l. a-year, with a yearly increase of 50l. to 100l., besides board and lodging, or a stipulated sum for either or both. The consequence is, that a better class of Europeans go there, and by the means at their disposal are able to provide themselves with conveniences and even luxuries, which are requisite to a comfortable residence in the tropics. The day is past when patients were killed by bleeding and by calomel. The late outcry and "furious attack," as you justly term it, is in a great measure originated and fostered by those who dislike the country as a station and their friends. This dislike is very natural in naval and military officers, who, frequently idle, must find time hang heavily on their hands; but why not be honest, and state the true grounds of their abuse of the country? When the slave-trade was brisk, and prizes and prize-money plentiful, naval men did not revile the "Coast" and climate as they now do.

I perfectly agree with you that the Coast of Africa may be made at least as healthy as the West India Islands, aye, and more so. Yellow fever is not a frequent visitor on this Coast, and at many places it is fortunately unknown. Let Governors and Administrators imitate the example partially set them of late at Lagos and Cape Coast, and improve the sanitary condition of the places under their rule; and let the Europeans, instead of abusing the "climate," adapt their habits to it, and there will soon be a vast diminution in the number of "victims!"', 'last_edit_date': '1867-04-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1867#article-25', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'On the Climate and Diseases of West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'So much has been said and written about the climate of West Africa, and it has been so long the fashion to abuse and condemn it without inquiry, that the medical profession, like the general public, have accepted and endorsed the common report as an established fact. It is therefore important to find such mischievous exaggerations combated by a medical officer, who writes of West Africa, not from hearsay evidence, but from the experience derived during a residence of twenty-three years in the colony of Sierra Leone and settlements of the Gold Coast. We make these remarks by way of introducing to more general notice the papers above noted, because they supply much valuable and novel information, not only regarding the diseases to which Europeans and natives are subject in West Africa, but because they furnish an interesting description of the topography of Sierra Leone and the Gold Coast.

Mr. Clarke is of opinion that the climate of West Africa, if fairly tested, can stand comparison in point of healthfulness with most of our colonies in the East or West Indies, where endemic and epidemic fevers, dysentery, with cholera to boot, prevail quite as frequently and fatally. He states "that formerly many officers in the English, Dutch, and Danish service resided upon the Gold Coast, some fourteen, twenty, and thirty years,* and enjoyed good health, although those in subordinate positions had to remove from one station to another." The fact ought no longer to be concealed, that half at least of the deaths and incapacities which occur amongst Europeans arise from errors of personal economy, and that the mortality lists are unfairly swelled by ascribing to the climate deaths which have been caused by accident or intemperance.

hh: The British Empire's inadequate health measures in colonial Africa, exemplified by the mishandling of smallpox in the Gambia, led to significant health crises that underscored the need for coordinated reform to protect both European and native populations.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively highlight the British Empire's inadequate health measures in colonial Africa, underscoring significant health crises that necessitated coordinated reform to protect both European and native populations. The textbook provides a broad overview of the inadequacies in health services, noting the uneven distribution that favored European settlers and administrators, with limited access for the African population. It mentions small-scale smallpox vaccination efforts, with notable disease reductions only in regions like the Gold Coast and southern Nigeria by the late 1930s, and emphasizes the low doctor-to-population ratio and limited medical budgets focused on Europeans until after World War I. However, it does not specifically address the mishandling of smallpox in the Gambia. In contrast, The African Times articles provide specific details about the health crises in the Gambia, highlighting the prevalence of smallpox and other diseases like yellow fever in areas such as Bathurst. The articles criticize the British authorities for inadequate sanitary regulations, neglect of vaccination, and official apathy, which led to outbreaks among both native and European populations. They call for coordinated reform and improved health measures, while acknowledging some efforts like appointing medical officers and vaccination attempts, though these are often seen as insufficient or hindered by bureaucracy. Together, these sources paint a comprehensive picture of the British Empire's inadequate health measures in colonial Africa, supporting the claim of significant health crises and the urgent need for reform.

Until near the end of the nineteenth century, Europeans were far more likely to succumb to indigenous diseases, as is evidenced by the death rates early in the century among British West African forces which were nine times as great among the European as among the African soldiers. 76 Europe was not medically well equipped for its African ventures. Many of the political problems that later plagued Uganda stem from this early partnership between the British and the Baganda.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The colonial economy: the former British zones', 'section_title': 'Ownership of the means of production', 'content': "It was neither a deliberate policy on the part of British colonial rulers which saved the land in British West Africa for the Africans during the inter-war period, nor was it because of the notorious reputation that West Africa had acquired as 'the White Man's Grave' by the late nineteenth century. As A. G. Hopkins has pointed out: The alleged unhealthiness of the tropics did not prevent the establish› ment of European plantations in the Belgian Congo, French Equatorial Africa, or Malaya, and it did not discourage serious applicants in West Africa either. Furthermore, the control of malaria and other tropical diseases was becoming more effective by the start of the twentieth century, and the so-called White Man's Grave was begin› ning to lose some of its unsavoury reputation. 20 What then did prevent the wholesale alienation of land in British West Africa? The first answer was what Hopkins has termed 'a fortuitous geo› logical fact', that West Africa was found to be not profusely rich in mineral deposits. The second was the failure of the move to establish plantations in West Africa. This failure was caused by a number of factors. The first was the vigorous opposition put up by the other British firms operating in these areas, which could not go in for the plantation system themselves. The second was the failure of the few plantations that were established owing to lack of capital and 'a considerable ignorance of tropical condition', shortage of labour and the shifts in world supply. The third and most important factor was the success of the West Africans themselves in meeting the demand for export crops such as cocoa, groundnuts and oil palm using their own simple methods on their small farms, which obviated the necessity of the plantation system in these areas. Another factor was the opposition that any attempt to seize any large areas or introduce large-scale forced labour for plantations would have generated among West Africans.$^{21}$ It was a combination of these factors that saved the people of British West Africa from the expropriation of their lands that was the fate of some of those in British East and Central Africa.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}]

[{'id': 519, 'article_title': 'Vaccination', 'full_section_title': 'Vaccination', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-10', 'issue_date': '23_01_1865', 'content': 'The neglect of vaccination in our colonies has been remarked upon in late medical reports, and in the opening discourses of the lectures in the great London medical schools. In one of the latter it is stated: "This neglect is seen from the occurrence of small-pox among our troops stationed in various parts of Her Majesty's dominions. It appears from an elaborate paper on the results of re-vaccination in the British army, as compared with Continental armies, lately read before the Epidemiological Society, that no portion of the empire is exempt from the scourge. From Canada to the Mediterranean, from the West Indies to Sierra Leone, and from the Cape of Good Hope to India and China, the same tale is to be heard of small-pox prevalent among the civil populations, and of more or less disease among the troops in consequence.'}, {'id': 2136, 'article_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '11-30-1871', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1872#article-16', 'issue_date': '23_01_1872', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—Dr. Mosse has responded to the article in the last _African Times_ treating on the introduction of small-pox into this place, and with reference to his reply, there are two matters to which I would particularly draw your attention.

1st. If proper precautions were taken, how came the hospital servant, Quashie Hajan, and a woman and daughter in Gothic House, to catch the disease? The poor woman and daughter died on the same day, a few hours only intervening between the two deaths.

2nd. The small-pox was never introduced here direct from the mail steamers; but was brought by the prisoner from Accra in May last on S.S. Biafra. We shall be glad if Dr. Mosse will refresh our memory as to when, and from what mail steamers this disease was introduced here direct.

Now a few words with reference to the address got up for Mr. Ussher when he was about to leave. You copied into your paper an article from a Cape Coast publication, exposing the state of Cape Coast Town, which was justly said to be one mass of filth—a veritable dung-hill; and you commented upon this in the _African Times_ in a way that stirred up official indignation at him whose article you thus copied in all quarters. To pacify them, he got up an address for Martyr Ussher. He had his own objects in view, of course; but not everybody followed the crafty lead, and I for one refused to sign. You cannot expose in too strong a language that system of addresses of sham praise. Pray continue to do your duty in a straightforward manner, without deference for colour, and God will reward you for your labours.

I hope you will not fail to let the Colonial-office know how, and with what object, that address given to Martyr Ussher was got up to pacify official displeasure.—Yours faithfully,'}, {'id': 3686, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1879#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_01_1879', 'content': 'With reference to statements which appeared in our columns with regard to Sunday work at the Gambia, we are informed that the occasion referred to was a solitary exception—one, no doubt, to be deplored, and a grievous error; but still an exception; and that Governor Gouldsbury is quite opposed to all such innovations. We are pleased to know this, and are glad of this early opportunity of stating it.

With regard to the sickness prevailing at the Gambia, mentioned in the letter of the 1st December, which we now publish, we are assured that, though virulent, it had not taken an epidemic form; and that there were not, so far, any signs of yellow fever. We greatly deplore the death of the Rev. H. Lamb, Wesleyan missionary, who, though we sometimes unfortunately differed with him, was a devoted and zealous pastor, whose loss will be greatly felt in the mission.—Ed. A.T.'}, {'id': 3721, 'article_title': 'THE FEVER AT BATHURST', 'full_section_title': 'THE FEVER AT BATHURST', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1879#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_02_1879', 'content': 'Weeping and mourning are at the Gambia; desolation and woe have fallen upon the unhappy town of Bathurst. A pestilential fever, against the threatened approaches of which no efforts at prevention were made by ignorant, incapable, and criminally erring officials, marched up from the foetid swamp, descended into the habitations of rich and poor, European and native; and death, terror, and dismay reigned supreme over all. The graphic letter on our 2nd page tells a little of the fatal tale. The Chief Magistrate, a young man in the full vigour and strength of life, four Europeans, and three natives, fell victims in one day. Well might the poor stricken people believe that this was only the vanguard of the Yellow Fever which had made its ravages at Senegal; and against the probable coming of which we had warned the besotted officials, who were too intent, each on his own little game, to heed our earnest entreaties to set their house in order. A heavy responsibility for the precious lives that have been taken away, should lie at the door of those whose duty it was to take adequate measures for the preservation of the public health. The large surplus which is the present boast of the Gambia Treasury—to create which the public service has in many ways been starved, and for creating which personal promotion is no doubt expected—is now made loathsome by the putrid corpses of victims whose lives have been sacrificed to it. Cynics and profound moralists equally affirm, that at the present time nothing is worshipped but money. The officials of Gambia and Sierra Leone may be adduced in support of the truth of this stigma. We earnestly hope the results will not be as fatal in the latter place as in the former. But when blundering, incapacity, and selfishness had done their worst, a kind Providence stepped in with its healthy Harmattan wind, and the pestilence gradually abated. We hope the influence of that health-giving wind will be felt at other parts of the Coast. Its absence last year was deeply deplored at Lagos, where small-pox and other fatal diseases then prevailed. But although the pestilence has been killed for a time at Bathurst by the Harmattan, we hope the present safety will not renew the guilty official apathy; and that the lives of the inhabitants will be deemed of more value than a few hundreds of pounds, more or less, in the Treasury. We say advisedly, guilty official apathy. Look at paragraphs in a letter from Bathurst in our last month's paper, page 2: "The streets and drains are very dirty, the effluvia from the latter very bad; the native yards in a filthy state; and though we pay local rates of 400l. a year, and there is a surplus now in the Treasury of 6,000l., yet not a penny can or will be spared for sanitary measures, because Mr. Bauer" (the Colonial Engineer) "will not act;" and yet we are face to face with a most sickly season; fever fast approaching to an epidemic in virulence; deaths are rapid and numerous, natives as well as Europeans. Still nothing is done!" Our correspondent goes on to say that some months ago, "We sent a petition to the Colonial Secretary, complaining of the inefficiency of the Engineer Department, asked for a Board of Inquiry, and engaged to substantiate all our charges. Dr. Gouldsbury" (the Administrator, who is a most intimate friend of Mr. Bauer and his family) "wrote to Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, to the effect that our statements were false; our complaints personal feeling; that Mr. Bauer was a 'most zealous and efficient officer,' &c. The Colonial Secretary wrote back to us to the effect that, in view of the Governor's report, he gave no credence to our statements, and would not grant any inquiry." In other words, the memorialists of Bathurst had the lie given to them, in the same way that it was also given to those of Sierra Leone; in both cases upon the mere ipse dixit of the erring Governor. Alas! what a commentary on all this is the fearful mortality that has plunged Bathurst into wailing, lamentation, and woe; a mortality distinctly traceable to Engineering and Administrative favouritism and incapacity or heartless indifference. Do not these events furnish a startling proof of the necessity of combined action on the West Coast, that all the settlements and populations, European merchants as well as natives, should have our constant help to bring their wants and just complaints in such a way before Her Majesty's Government, that it shall not be in the power of erring officials, however high their grade, to call down Imperial insult on an injured people; and obstruct the course of reforms on which the lives of the inhabitants and the prosperity of the Settlement depend?'}]

We have, as our readers well know, felt the most serious apprehensions that the yellow fever, which had visited Senegal, would descend to Bathurst, as offering a most tempting field for it to revel in. Happily, however, according to latest advices, it seems to have spent its energies at St. Louis, and has died out there. But we were not surprised to hear that while the yellow fever was at the Senegal, a virulent smallpox should have broken out among the natives at Bathurst, it having been almost invariably the case that whenever yellow fever made its appearance among the Europeans on that part of the Coast, there should be a great mortality from small-pox among the natives, who do not suffer from yellow fever, as neither do the Europeans from the native small-pox. Unfortunately, owing to the pressure of the scare at Cape Coast, Sir Samuel will not have been able to make that visit and inquiry. The strange neglect by British authorities in almost all the Coast towns of ordinary means to purify the atmosphere is a great disgrace to us as a nation. What has been done at Calcutta, in the East Indies, once as unhealthy a residence for Europeans as any one of the West Coast towns, might long ago have been done in these also. We would ask our readers to glance for a moment at the complaints about the state of Quittah, where a considerable revenue is already raised, and where a much larger one might, it is stated, be raised by a modified scale of Customs' duties, such as would put an end to the temptation of smuggling from the neighbouring sea-coast villages without British jurisdiction. Disgraceful is a word scarcely strong enough to apply to such a state of things. It is a lamentable fact that, so far as the Government is concerned, we do not carry civilization and civilizing efforts with us. Our officers are content to sit upon dung-heaps, surrounded by the most atmospheric-poisoning filth, to collect their Customs' duties; and then we complain of the fatal atmospheric impurities of so many of the sea-coast towns. Our support may not be of much importance, but, such as it is, it will be heartily given to him in every effort to make British rule a mighty civilizing agent and a real blessing to the Gold Coast countries and their people.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.736, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SMALLPOX AT CAPE COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'WE deplore, though we are not surprised, that the loathsome epidemic, smallpox, is committing its ravages at Cape Coast. The filthy condition of that town, fully exposed in late numbers of this journal, must without doubt tend to the increase of its severity, as well as to the number of attacks. A few years since (six, we believe), after great ravages of smallpox at Accra, when Dr. Gunn, who was at that time on the station, vaccinated a very considerable number of the native population, and thus, it was considered, did much to arrest the onward progress of the fatal disorder, we more than once called attention to the subject, in the hope that the British authorities in the settlements of this country on the Coast, would take some effectual measures for bringing the population gradually under that degree of protection which vaccination undoubtedly affords. We do not say what that degree is; but, looking at the European population in the present day, with their smooth, unmarked faces, we find they present so marked a contrast to those of the generation passed away, as to establish beyond dispute that the degree is a very considerable one. It is, therefore, greatly to be regretted that our self-martyrising, zealous Administrators on the West Coast, while "wearing themselves to the very verge of the grave" in their arduous exertions for the good of the native population, have not paid more attention to this important matter of the employment of preventive means for arresting the spread of that terrible scourge of Africa—smallpox—among the native people. In another column we publish a short account of an experience in this matter in the East Indies, where the prejudice against, or rather disbelief in the benefit of vaccination, has far exceeded anything of the kind experienced in Africa. Indeed, Dr. Gunn assured us at the time of the Accra outbreak, the people came willingly and with strong expressions of gratitude to obtain the protection (then proved in their eyes to be real) which vaccination affords. Whether the self-made Martyr Administrator of Cape Coast returns there, or some other aspirant martyr be sent out, we beg once again to express the hope that, by the formation of a vaccine institution, or by giving a fee per head to the Army and Colonial Surgeons for every child or adult properly and effectively vaccinated by them, or by some other active and dependable means, the native population in the future may be less exposed to the ravages of smallpox than it has been in the past. The records of travellers and explorers establish incontestably that smallpox is the great fatal disease of Africa. Among the great and precious benefits which European civilisation bestows on Africa, let this be one, that we make the results of our own experience instrumental in saving African lives from that fell destroyer. The propagation of vaccination ought to be actively carried on from every British settlement.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1871#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.732, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Introduction of Present Epidemic of Small-pox into Cape Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—That dreadful disease the small-pox is raging fearfully here, and friends dear and precious in our eyes, and who might otherwise have been our joy for many long years to come, have been swept away by it. It becomes, then, our duty to hold up to public and superior official censure those in authority here who allowed such a disease to get into our colonial hospital, without taking proper precautions for the safety of other patients there, and of all the other inhabitants of this place. Many of us are mourning the death of our dearest friends through the gross and culpable neglect of our rulers. The fatal disease was brought here by a prisoner from Accra, landed here in May last from the steamship Biafra. Allow me, then, to ask the Colonial Surgeon, through your columns, whether it is his duty to receive patients into the hospital without knowing under what diseases they are suffering; whether he was aware that this prisoner was afflicted with small-pox, and admitted him into the hospital without those precautions for the safety of others that ought to have been taken, whereby hundreds are dying of the infection introduced by that prisoner from Accra. I say that he is responsible for the lives of those who are thus hurried into untimely graves; and I earnestly beg of you to expose this fatal negligence of those in authority. At the present time those who suffer under the disease are quartered in the centre of the town; hence people inhaling the poisonous odour are infected, and coffins are passing with dead bodies every day.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-08-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1871#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.716, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It seems that this malignant disease which carried off so many victims last year in the towns and villages of the Coast, is still far from having disappeared in the neighbourhood of Cape Coast Castle. It will be remembered that the local government very praiseworthily dispatched Dr. Horton in the direction of Appam, Mumford, and other places, to render assistance to the natives under the sad calamity; and that he vaccinated some thousands of them, notwithstanding the opposition of the Fetish priests. Dr. Horton received the thanks of the Right Hon. the Secretary of State for the Colonies, for the self-devotion and courage of which he gave proof on that occasion; and we are surprised that after such high official approval of the measures then adopted, the British local authorities have not, by some means or other, carried out a general system of vaccination of the entire population of Cape Coast Town, among whom the Acting Administrator, chief magistrate, and all the civil officials reside. The small-pox is a deadly disease in every part of the world to which it makes its visit, but has always been especially fatal among intertropical populations. It has been a greater depopulator of West Africa than any other disease known along the West Coast; and we hope that wherever the British authorities possess influence, that influence will be earnestly exerted in inducing the natives to be vaccinated. Vaccination is one of the real blessings of civilization; and we think it is the duty of the British authorities on the West Coast to do all in their power to induce the people to accept the protection which it undoubtedly offers.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.699, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Great Britain: Her Colonies and Settlements', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'introduction into at least the seats of government such as Cape Coast, Accra, and Lagos, of such sanitary measures as would remove from them their tropical and uncivilized unhealthiness. Very little, however, has been done in this direction; as the constant complaints from Lagos and Cape Coast, chronicled in their local journals, but too clearly establish. There is no blame lying at our door for this. Fifteen or more years ago we reproached one of the Governors as being satisfied to live on a dung-heap, if only he might follow his own vicious propensities; and the Governors may have become more moral, but they do not seem to have become more delicate. The public discussions in such a Colonial Representative Chamber sitting in London, as we have suggested, would soon lead to a change for the better in such important matters. There can be no reason why Accra, Cape Coast, Lagos, and other towns should not be made as healthy as Calcutta now is; Calcutta, than which no more fatally unhealthy place existed, when British rule was first established itself there. British West Africa, is, in a word, suffering under British contemptuous neglect, which the children of the present generation will deplore.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1883#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.702, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EPIDEMIC ON THE AFRICAN COAST', 'section_title': '', 'content': '### EPIDEMIC ON THE AFRICAN COAST.\n\n**February 11.**—Information has been received in Liverpool this morning of a serious outbreak of small-pox at Bathurst, British Gambia, and also that quarantine restrictions are again in force at Goree, Senegal. It is supposed that yellow fever has made its appearance again at the latter place.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.726, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Official Delinquencies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—About ten months ago small-pox was raging here, and the number of deaths was very large, so the local Government had to appoint an Acting-Assistant Colonial Surgeon to specially look after the small-pox cases, and supervise vaccination. Dr. Taylor, of Sierra Leone, was offered the appointment and accepted it, and fulfilled his duties to the satisfaction of everyone. But a jealous feeling towards that gentleman, on the part of certain of the leading officials, caused an application to be sent to the Colonial Office to send out a doctor from England, and in due time Dr. W. Allan arrived here, and superseded Dr. Taylor, who afterwards left the Colony in disgust. Well, small-pox died away, and Bathurst became healthy; then the Senior Colonial Surgeon, Dr. Spilsbury, went to England on leave of absence, leaving Dr. Allan to perform his duties and look after his private practice (which is a lucrative one) among the European houses. Previous to Dr. Spilsbury going on leave, Captain Roche, the First Writer, or, as he is called here, "the Governor\'s Secretary," went on leave; and for a time His Excellency managed to do without a "Secretary." But finding this inconvenient, he asked the Chief Clerk at Government House to undertake the duties; and he refused unless he was paid an extra salary—and quite right, too. The Governor then applied to Dr. Allan to take the post, and he accepted it. The consequence is that now his whole day is taken up with his quill-driving duties in the office in Government House, and he has little time to attend to his duties as medical officer; so his patients have to suffer. He tells his patients he has not got time to visit them; that "If he got ten dollars a visit he could not come to them;" that "if he had them all at the Colonial Hospital he might manage to look after them" (i.e., give the dispenser instructions, and leave him to do the best he could), "but he cannot undertake to attend them properly now, as he is the greater part of the day at Government House." The natives seemed anxious to have the matter investigated, and were eagerly waiting the arrival of Governor Freeling for that purpose.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1879#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.695, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'All labour is performed by the domestic slaves of the family, who, as a rule, are kindly treated, and are not often parted with, except under circumstances of necessity.\n\nThere is some reason to suppose that coloured traders and trading agents, when following their avocations at a distance from the settlements, occasionally engage in slave-dealing transactions with the natives; but these operations are conducted beyond British jurisdiction, and as yet it has been found impossible to bring any case home to an offender.\n\nIn point of unhealthiness the climate of the Gambia probably varies little from that of the other settlements. J. Chamberlain, the Secretary for the Colonies, in reply, said: "I regret to state during the months in question, which were exceptionally unhealthy, no less than five deaths occurred among the English civil officials, of whom there are about thirty, and three were invalided home, besides two (including the Governor) who were invalided to the Canary Islands. hh: Tropical diseases like yellow fever significantly impacted European maritime activities and trade in Africa, prompting advancements in maritime health practices, the imposition of quarantine measures, and the evolution of public health policies in the 19th century.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide contrasting perspectives on the impact of tropical diseases like yellow fever on European maritime activities and trade in Africa during the 19th century. The textbook primarily focuses on the broader impact of diseases on European and African populations within Africa, the establishment of medical schools, and the development of health services, while noting the challenges faced by Europeans due to tropical diseases and the delayed attention to tropical medicine. However, it does not specifically link these issues to maritime activities or trade, nor does it discuss advancements in maritime health practices, quarantine measures, or public health policies in this context. In contrast, The African Times articles offer detailed support for the claim, frequently mentioning outbreaks of yellow fever and other diseases that disrupted trade and communication, affecting both local populations and European settlers. The articles highlight quarantine measures imposed by governments, such as the Portuguese and French responses to yellow fever outbreaks, and discuss the impact of diseases on ships and their crews, exemplified by the yellow fever outbreak on the brigantine St. Helier's and subsequent quarantine at ports like Teneriffe. They also note medical reinforcements and calls for improved sanitary measures in British settlements, underscoring the evolution of public health policies. Additionally, the articles reflect a debate on the perceived severity of the West African climate, suggesting that with proper health precautions, the risks could be mitigated, adding complexity to the understanding of tropical diseases' impact during this period.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that tropical diseases like yellow fever significantly impacted European maritime activities and trade in Africa, leading to advancements in maritime health practices, quarantine measures, and public health policies in the 19th century. The articles frequently mention outbreaks of yellow fever and other diseases, such as smallpox, affecting both the local populations and European settlers, which disrupted trade and communication. For instance, the articles report on the quarantine measures imposed by the Portuguese Government and the French Government's response to yellow fever outbreaks in Senegal, indicating a recognition of the need for public health interventions. Additionally, the articles discuss the impact of diseases on ships and their crews, such as the yellow fever outbreak on the brigantine St. Helier's, and the subsequent quarantine measures at ports like Teneriffe. The mention of medical reinforcements and the call for improved sanitary measures in British settlements further highlight the evolution of public health policies in response to these health crises. However, the articles also reflect a debate on the severity of the West African climate, with some opinions suggesting that the climate is not inherently more dangerous than other tropical regions, and that proper health precautions could mitigate the risks. This nuance adds depth to the claim by illustrating the complexity of perceptions and responses to tropical diseases during this period.

We must earnestly call the attention of our Parliamentary friends to this important subject. The expenses of the West Coast squadron ought to be kept down to the lowest figure compatible with its efficiency, and no ship ought to be sent out to a fever climate that is not so constructed as to give the strongest possible guarantees for the preservation of the valuable health and lives of Her Majesty's sailors. **RULES.**

1. Lay the drowned man at once flat on his stomach with his face to the ground, and a folded coat or bundle under his chest. 2. The Active has proceeded to St. Helena to give leave to her crew.'}, {'id': 3914, 'article_title': 'Yellow Fever at Home and Abroad', 'full_section_title': 'Yellow Fever at Home and Abroad', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1879#article-18', 'issue_date': '01_12_1879', 'content': 'A report, that created some alarm for a few hours, arose in the West India Docks on Monday last, to the effect that a case of yellow fever had arrived, and was on board a vessel called the J.
